Title:: 70 S.J. Res. 47 (Star (No.) Print of an Amendment)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States fixing the commencement of the terms of President and Vice President and Members of Congress and fixing the time of the assembling of Congress.
TEXT_Content:
70TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 47

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH

9, 1928

The House considered and amended the Senate joint resolution by striking
out all after the resolving clause and inserting the so-called White
amendment as a substitute, which latter as amended in the Committee
of the Whole House on the state of the Union was reported to the House
and agreed to. Upon the question on agreeing to the Senate joint
resolution as amended by the* White substitute it was decided in the
negative, two-thirds not voting in favor thereof

The following is the text of the
ORIGINAL SENATE JOINT RESOLUTION
for which the White amendment, as amended, was a substitute

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
fixing the commencement of the terms of President and Vice
President and Members of Congress and fixing the time of
the assembling of Congress.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment of the Constitution be, and hereby is,

5

proposed to the States, to become valid as a part of said
ic

3-12-28

1

Constitution when ratified by the legislatures of the several

2

States as provided by the Constitution:

3

"ARTICLE

4

"SECTION

—

1. The terms of the President and Vice

5

President shall end at noon on the 15th day of January,

(}

and the terms of Senators and Representatives at noon on

7

the 2d day of January, of the years in which such terms

8

would have ended if this article had not been ratified; and

9

the terms of their successors shall then begin.

10

"SEC.

2. The Congress snail assemble at least once in

11

every year, and such meeting shall begin at noon on the 2d

12

day of January, unless they shall by law appoint a different

13

day.

14

"SEC.

3. If the House of Representatives has not

35

chosen a President, whenever the right of choice devolves

16

upon them, before the time fixed for the beginning of his

17

term, then the Vice President shall act as President, as

18

in the case of the death or other constitutional disability of

19

the President.

20

case of the failure to choose the Vice President before the

21

time fixed for the beginning of his term, declaring what

22

officer shall then act as President, and such officer shall act

23

accordingly until the House of Representatives chooses a

24

President or until the Senate chooses a Vice President.

25
20

The Congress shall by law provide for the

" SEC. 4. This amendment shall take effect on the 15th
dav of October after its ratification."

1

The following is the text of the

2

WHITE AMENDMENT

3

as amended in Committee of the Whole House on the state

4

of the Union and in the House, but which was rejected on the

5

final vote:

6

That the following article is proposed as an amend-

7

ment to the Constitution of the United States, which shall

£

be valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitu-

9

tion when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the

10

several States:

11
12

"ARTICLE

"

SECTION

—

1. The terms of the President and Vice

18

President shall end at noon on the 24th day of January,

14

and the terms of Senators and Representatives at noon on

15

the 4th day of January, of the years in which such

16

terms would have ended if this article had not been ratified;

17

and the terms of their successors shall then begin.

lg

"SEC.

2. The Congress shall assemble at least once

19

in every year, and such meeting shall be on the 4th day of

20

January, unless they shall by law appoint a different day.

21

"

SEC.

3. If the President elect dies, then the Vice Presi-

22

dent elect shall become President.

If a President is not

23

chosen before the time fixed for the beginning of his term,

2*1

or if the President elect fails to qualify, then the Vice

25

President elect shall act as President until a President has

26

qualified; and the Congress may by law provide for the case

4
1

where neither a President elect nor a Vice President elect has

2

qualified, declaring who shall then act as President or the

3

manner in which a qualified person shall be selected, and such

4

person shall act accordingly until a President or Vice Presi-

5

dent has qualified.

6

" SEC. 4. The Congress may by law provide for the

7

case of the death of any of the persons from whom the

8

House of Representatives may choose a President whenever

9

the right of choice devolves upon them, and for the case of

10

the death of any of the persons from whom the Senate may

11

choose a Vice President whenever the right of choice devolves

12

upon them.

13

" SEC. 5. Sections 1 and 2 shall take effect on the

14

30th day of November of the year following the year in

15

which this article is ratified.

16

" SEC. 6. This article shall be inoperative unless it

17

shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Constitu-

18

tion by the legislatures of three-fourths of the States within

19

seven years from the date of the submission hereof to the •

20

States by the Congress, and the act of ratification shall be

21

by legislatures, the entire membership of at least one branch

22

of which shall have been elected subsequent to such date of

23

submission."

Title:: 109 H. J. Res. 8 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish the electoral college and to provide for the direct popular election of the President and Vice President of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

109TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 8

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish
the electoral college and to provide for the direct popular election of
the President and Vice President of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 4, 2005
Mr. GENE GREEN of Texas (for himself, Mr. BAIRD, and Mr. DELAHUNT) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to abolish the electoral college and to provide
for the direct popular election of the President and Vice
President of the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein),
4
5

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.

This joint resolution may be cited as the ‘‘Every Vote

6 Counts Amendment’’.

2
1
2

SEC. 2. CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT.

The following article is proposed as an amendment

3 to the Constitution of the United States, which shall be
4 valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitu5 tion when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of
6 the several States within seven years after the date of its
7 submission for ratification:
8
9

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The President and Vice President shall

10 be elected by the people of the several States and the dis11 trict constituting the seat of government of the United
12 States.
13

‘‘SECTION 2. The electors in each State shall have

14 the qualifications requisite for electors of Senators and
15 Representatives in Congress from that State, except that
16 the legislature of any State may prescribe less restrictive
17 qualifications with respect to residence and Congress may
18 establish uniform residence and age qualifications.
19

‘‘SECTION 3. The persons having the greatest number

20 of votes for President and Vice President shall be elected.
21

‘‘SECTION 4. Each elector shall cast a single vote

22 jointly applicable to President and Vice President. Names
23 of candidates may not be joined unless they shall have con24 sented thereto and no candidate may consent to the can25 didate’s name being joined with that of more than one
26 other person.

3
1

‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress may by law provide for

2 the case of the death of any candidate for President or
3 Vice President before the day on which the President-elect
4 or Vice President-elect has been chosen, and for the case
5 of a tie in any election.
6

‘‘SECTION 6. This article shall apply with respect to

7 any election for President and Vice President held after
8 the expiration of the 1-year period which begins on the
9 date of the ratification of this article.’’.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 104 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give citizens of the United States the right to propose amendments to the Constitution by an initiative process.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 104

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give
citizens of the United States the right to propose amendments to the
Constitution by an initiative process.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. HOEKSTRA

JULY 26, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to give citizens of the United States the right
to propose amendments to the Constitution by an initiative process.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with-

2
1 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica2 tion:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people shall have the right to pro-

5 pose amendments to the Constitution through the initia6 tive process provided in this article.
7

‘‘SECTION 2. A petition proposing an amendment to

8 the Constitution shall be submitted to an officer of the
9 Government of the United States whom the Congress shall
10 designate by law. Each petition shall contain the text of
11 the proposed amendment. Each petition shall be signed
12 by at least 3 percent of the whole number of people, in
13 each of at least 10 States, who voted in the most recent
14 election for President, or for electors for President, occur15 ring before the date on which the petition is submitted
16 to the officer designated by Congress, and the total num17 ber of signatures on such petition shall be at least 3 per18 cent of the whole number of people, from all of the several
19 States, who voted in such election. All such signatures
20 shall be collected within the 18-month period ending on
21 the date the petition is submitted to the officer designated
22 by the Congress.
23

‘‘Within 90 days after a petition is submitted to the

24 officer designated by the Congress, such officer shall de25 termine the validity of the signatures contained in the pe•HJ 104 IH

3
1 tition. If the petition contains the required number of valid
2 signatures, the officer shall certify the petition and shall
3 direct the chief executive officer in each State to place a
4 copy of the proposed amendment contained in the petition
5 on the ballot in the first election (other than an election
6 to fill a vacancy) for Members of the House of Representa7 tives which is held at least 120 days after such certifi8 cation. The Congress shall by law establish procedures for
9 the preparation and submission of any such petition and
10 for the validation of signatures on such petition.
11

‘‘SECTION 3. If the amendment proposed under this

12 article receives a majority of the votes cast in three-fifths
13 of the several States, the amendment shall be deemed pro14 posed to the States for ratification under article V of this
15 Constitution. Congress shall provide by law which of the
16 eligible modes of ratification shall be used.
17

‘‘SECTION 4. The people in each State voting under

18 this article shall have the qualification requisite for elec19 tors of the most numerous branch of the State legislature.
20 The Congress shall by law prescribe the manner in which
21 the results of the voting conducted under this article shall
22 be ascertained and declared.’’.

Æ

•HJ 104 IH

Mr. HOLMAN introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
providing for the election of United States Senators by a direct vote of the people of the several States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representa-

2

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol-

lowing amendment he proposed to the legislatures of the se'v-

5

eral States, which, when ratified by three-fourths of said leg-

6

islatures, shall become and be a part of the Constitution,

11

I.

12

for six years; and the electors in each State shall have the

15

qualifications requisite for electors of the most numerous

16

branch of the State legislatures; and each Senator shall have

17

one vote."

Title:: 49 H. Res. 131 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States in relation to the election of United States Senators.
TEXT_Content:
49TH

COTCKESS,

TT

TJ T71 Of

1 O 4

Itf THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MAKCH

1,1886.

Read, twice, referred to the Committee ou the Judiciary, aud ordered to be printed.

Mr. HILL introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLU
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
in relation to the election of United States Senators.
Whereas the Constitution of the United States provides for and
constitutes three co-ordinate departments of Government,
namely, "the legislative," "the executive," and "the judicial," to which are confided all the powers granted by the
people and the States to the Federal Government; and
Whereas each of these departments has distinct functions, powers,
and duties clearly defined by the Constitution, and each is independent of either or both the others in the exercise of the
powers or the performance of the duties confided and enjoined
by the Constitution; and
Whereas the Constitution, by direct words, conferred on the President of the United States, the head of the executive department, the power of appointing and removing all subordinate
officials in the executive and judicial departments, with the
sole limitation that certain appointments should be "by and
with the advice and consent of the Senate;" and
Whereas the Presidents of the United States, since the establishment of the Constitution, have exercised this power of appoint •

merit and removal at will, save when the same has been restricted by proper and constitutional methods; and
Whereas the Senate of the United States, a subordinate branch of
the legislative department of the Government, possessing only
limited powers of legislation, and absolutely without power
under the Constitution, except in connection with the House
of Representatives, to do any act or thing but consider treaties
and nominations, is now attempting to interfere with the power
confided solely to the President of removing officials: Therefore,
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

3

[two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That section

4

three of the Constitution of the United States be amended so

5

as to read as follows:

6

"SEC.

3 The Senate of the United States shall be com-

7

posed of two Senators from each State, chosen every sixth

8

year by the people of the several States ; and the electors in

9

each State shall have the qualifications requisite for electors

10

of the most numerous branch of the State legislature."

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
fixing the commencement of the terms of President and Vice
President and Members of Congress, and fixing the time of
the assembling of Congress.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

6

said Constitution when ratified by the legislatures of the

7

several States as provided by the Constitution:

ARTICLE

3

7

terms would have ended if this article had not been ratified,

8

and the terms of their successors shall then begin.

9

SEC.

10

every year and such meeting shall be on the first Monday in

11

January unless they shall by law appoint a different day.

12

13

chosen a President, whenever the right of choice devolves

14

upon them, before the time fixed for the beginning of his

15

term, then the Vice President chosen for the same term shall

16

act as President until the House of Representatives chooses a

17

President; but if the House of Representatives has net chosen

18

a President before neon en the fourth day of March nest

19

following? then the Viee President shall become President

20

during the remainder el the term; and the Congress shall by

21

law provide that in the event the Vice President has not been

22

chosen before the time fixed for the beginning of his term

23

what officer shall then act as President, and such officer shall

3
1

act accordingly until the House of Representatives chooses a

2

President, or until the Senate chooses a Vice President.

3
4

" SEC. 4. This amendment shall take effect on the
fifteenth dav of October after its ratification."

H. J. RES. 48

that the rights extended by the Constitution are the rights of natural
persons only.

KHANNA, Mr. RYAN, Mr. BLUMENAUER, Mr. TAKANO, Ms. SCHAKOWSKY, Ms. BONAMICI, and Ms. GABBARD) submitted the following
joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States providing that the rights extended by the Constitution are the rights of natural persons only.

Title:: 106 H. J. Res. 21 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States establishing English as the official language of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

106TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 21

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States establishing
English as the official language of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 19, 1999
Mr. DOOLITTLE (for himself, Mr. MANZULLO, Mr. CRAMER, Mr. GUTKNECHT,
Mr. STUMP, Mr. TANCREDO, Mr. GOODE, and Mrs. CHENOWETH) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee
on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States establishing English as the official language of
the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years after the date of its submission
9 for ratification:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The English language shall be the offi-

3 cial language of the United States. As the official lan4 guage, the English language shall be used for all public
5 acts including every order, resolution, vote or election, and
6 for all records and judicial proceedings of the Government
7 of the United States and the governments of the several
8 States.
9

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress and the States shall en-

10 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 3 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States limiting the period of time United States Senators and Representatives may serve.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 3

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States limiting
the period of time United States Senators and Representatives may serve.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 4, 1995
Mr. INGLIS of South Carolina (for himself, Mr. DORNAN, Mr. SANFORD, Mr.
ARMEY, Mr. GOSS, Mr. HUTCHINSON, Mr. DICKEY, Mr. ROYCE, Mr.
HOEKSTRA, Mr. LEWIS of Kentucky, Mr. SALMON, Mr. GRAHAM, Mr.
DAVIS, Mr. HEINEMAN, Mr. CHABOT, Mrs. SMITH of Washington, Mr.
GANSKE, Mr. CHRYSLER, Mr. ENSIGN, Mr. COOLEY, Mr. CHRISTENSEN,
Mr. FOX, Mr. CALVERT, Mr. NETHERCUTT, Mr. SHADEGG, Mr.
METCALF, Mr. WHITFIELD, Mr. BASS, Mr. SOLOMON, Mr. FORBES, Mr.
BLUTE, Mr. SMITH of Texas, Mr. BACHUS, Mr. KIM, Mr. RIGGS, Mr.
LONGLEY, Mr. COX, Mr. SMITH of Michigan, Mr. BAKER of California,
Mr. WELDON of Florida, Mr. COBURN, Mr. RADANOVICH, Mr. ROTH, Mr.
PACKARD, Mr. STUMP, Mr. EVERETT, Mr. THORNBERRY, Mr. ALLARD,
Mr. BONO, Mr. CUNNINGHAM, Mr. TATE, Ms. DUNN, and Mr. TALENT)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States limiting the period of time United States Senators
and Representatives may serve.

2
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States:
9
10

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person may serve in Congress more

11 than 2 full terms as a Senator. No person may serve in
12 Congress more than 3 full terms as a Representative.
13

‘‘SECTION 2. Service as a Senator or Representative

14 before this article takes effect shall not be taken into ac15 count in determining service under section 1.’’.

Æ

•HJ 3 IH

Title:: 106 H. J. Res. 53 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Ernest J. Istook Jr. (R - OK)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for a balanced budget for the United States Government and for greater accountability in the enactment of tax legislation.
TEXT_Content:
IA

106TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 53

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for a balanced budget for the United States Government and for greater
accountability in the enactment of tax legislation.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MAY 12, 1999
Mr. ISTOOK (for himself, Mr. ARMEY, Mr. CAMPBELL, Mr. COBURN, Mr. COX,
Mrs. CUBIN, Mr. DEMINT, Mr. DOOLITTLE, Mrs. EMERSON, Mr. GOODE,
Mr. HALL of Texas, Mr. HERGER, Mr. HOEKSTRA, Mr. SAM JOHNSON
of Texas, Mr. LAHOOD, Mr. MCCRERY, Mr. MCINTOSH, Mr. PETERSON
of Pennsylvania, Mr. PETRI, Mr. PITTS, Mr. SANFORD, Mr. SCHAFFER,
Mr. SHIMKUS, Mr. TALENT, Mr. TERRY, Mr. BURTON of Indiana, and
Mr. TANCREDO) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget for the United
States Government and for greater accountability in the
enactment of tax legislation.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all

2
1 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
2 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
3 States within seven years after the date of its submission
4 for ratification:
5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall

7 not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless three8 fifths of the whole number of each House of Congress shall
9 by a rollcall vote provide by law for a specified excess of
10 outlays over receipts.
11

‘‘SECTION 2. Total receipts shall include all receipts

12 of the United States Government except those derived
13 from borrowing, and except for any suprlus within the
14 Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and
15 the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Total out16 lays shall include all outlays of the United States Govern17 ment except for those for repayment of debt principal.
18

‘‘SECTION 3. The limit on the debt of the United

19 States held by the public shall not be increased, unless
20 three-fifths of the whole number of each House shall pro21 vide by law for such an increase by a rollcall vote.
22

‘‘SECTION 4. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

23 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
24 United States Government for that fiscal year which con25 forms to the requirements of this article.
•HJ 53 IH

3
1

‘‘SECTION 5. No bill to increase revenue shall become

2 law unless approved by a majority of the whole number
3 of each House by a rollcall vote.
4

‘‘SECTION 6. Solely to the extent necessary for addi-

5 tional military funding, the Congress may waive the provi6 sions of this article for any fiscal year in which a declara7 tion of war is in effect, or in which the United States is
8 engaged in military conflict which causes an imminent and
9 serious military threat to national security and is so de10 clared by a joint resolution, adopted by a majority of the
11 whole number of each House, which becomes law.
12

‘‘SECTION 7. The Congress shall enforce and imple-

13 ment this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely
14 on estimates of outlays and receipts.
15

‘‘SECTION 8. This article shall take effect beginning

16 with the first fiscal year beginning after its ratification.’’.

Æ

•HJ 53 IH

Title:: 105 S. J. Res. 15 (Introduced in the Senate)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to clarify the intent of the Constitution to neither prohibit nor require public school prayer.
TEXT_Content:
II

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 15

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to clarify
the intent of the Constitution to neither prohibit nor require public
school prayer.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
Mr. BYRD

FEBRUARY 6, 1997
introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to clarify the intent of the Constitution to neither
prohibit nor require public school prayer.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution, which shall be valid to all intents and purposes
6 as part of the Constitution when ratified by the legisla7 tures of three-fourths of the several States within seven
8 years after the date of its submission to the States for
9 ratification:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Nothing in this Constitution, or amend-

3 ments thereto, shall be construed to prohibit or require

Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen on account of birth in the United States unless a parent is a United States citizen at the time of the birth.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
that no person born in the United States will be a United States
citizen on account of birth in the United States unless a parent is
a United States citizen at the time of the birth.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MAY 17, 1995
Mr. CALLAHAN (for himself, Mr. STUMP, Mr. EVERETT, and Mr. TRAFICANT)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen on account of
birth in the United States unless a parent is a United
States citizen at the time of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with-

2
1 in seven years after the date of its submission to the
2 States for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

5 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
6 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
7 of birth in the United States unless the mother or father
8 of the person is a citizen of the United States at the time
9 of the birth.
10

‘‘SEC. 2. The Congress shall have power to enforce

11 this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

TEXT_Content:
87TII CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
13,19(31
Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary and ordered to be printed
SKITEMBKR

AMENDMENT
(IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE)

Intended to be proposed by Mr. MTJNDT (for himself, Mr.
THURMOND, Mr. MORTON, Mr. EONG, Mr. RRUSKA, Mr.
GOLD WATER, and Mr. MCCLELLAN) to the joint resolution
(S.J. Res. 12) proposing an amendment to the Constitution
of the United States providing for the election of President
and Vice President, viz: Strike out all after the resolving
clause and insert in lieu thereof the following:
1

That the following article is proposed as an amendment

2 to the Constitution of the United States which shall be valid
3 to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
4 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
5 States:
9-13-61

A

"ARTICLE —

1
2

"SECTION

1. Each. State shall choose a number of

3 electors of President and Vice President equal to the whole
4 number of Senators and Representatives to which the State
5 may be entitled in the Congress; but no Senator or Rep6 resentative, or person holding an office of trust or profit under
7 the United States, shall be chosen an elector.
8

"The electors to which a State is entitled by virtue of

9 its Senators shall be elected by the people thereof, and the
10 electors to which it is entitled by virtue of its Representa11 tives shall be elected by the people within single-elector dis12 tricts established by the legislature, thereof; such, districts to
13 be composed of compact and contiguous territory, containing
14 as nearly as practicable the number of persons which entitle
15 the State to one Representative in the Congress; and such
16 districts when formed shall not be altered until another census
17 has been taken.
18
"Before being chosen elector each candidate for the
19 office shall officially declare the persons for whom he will
20 vote for President and Vice President, which declaration
21

shall be binding on any successor. In choosing electors of

22

President and Vice President the voters in each State shall

23

have the qualifications requisite for electors of the most nu-

24

merous branch of the State legislature.

25

icrr

'The electors shall meet in their respective States, fill

1

any vacancies in their number as directed by the State legis-

2 lature, and vote by signed ballot for President and Vice
3 President, one of whom, at least, shall not be an inhabitant
4 of the same State with themselves; they shall name in their
5 ballots the person voted for as President, and in distinct
6 ballots the person voted for as Vice President; and they
7 shall make distinct lists of all persons voted for as President,
8 and of all persons voted for as Vice President, and of the
9 number of votes for each, excluding therefrom any votes
10 for persons other than those named by an elector before
H he was chosen, unless one or both of the persons so named
12 be deceased, which lists they shall sign, and certify, and
13 transmit sealed to the seat of government of the United
14 States, directed to the President of the Senate; the President
of the Senate shall, in the presence of the Senate and the
House of Representatives, open all the certificates and the
1'

votes shall then be coimted; the person having the greatest

1° number of votes for President shall be the President, if such
I9 number be a majority of the whole number of electors chosen;
and the person having the greatest number of votes for
Vice President shall be the Vice President, if such a number
22

be a majority of the whole number of electors chosen.
"If no person voted for as President has a majority of

24

the whole number of electors, then from the persons having
the three highest numbers on the list of persons voted for as

1 President, the Senate and the House of Representatives,
2 assembled and voting as individual members of one body,
3 shall choose immediately, by ballot, the President; a quorum
4 for such purpose shall be three-fourths of the whole number
5 of the Senators and Representatives, and a majority of the
6 whole number shall be necessary to a choice; if additional
7 ballots be necessary, the choice on the fifth ballot shall be
8 between the two persons having the highest number of votes
9 on the fourth ballot.
10

"If no person voted for as Vice President has a majority

11 of the whole number of electors, then the Vice President shall
12 be chosen from the person having the three highest numbers'
13 on the list of persons voted for as Vice President in the same
14 manner as herein provided for choosing the President. But
15 no person constitutionally ineligible to the office of President
16 shall be eligible to that of Vice President of the United
1? States.
18

"SEC.

2. The Congress may by law provide for the

1^ case of the death of any of the persons from whom the Senate
20 and the House of Representatives may choose a President or
21 a Vice President whenever the right of choice shall have de22 volved upon them.
23

"SEC.

3. This article supersedes the second paragraph of

24 section 1, article II, of the Constitution, the twelfth article of

1 amendment to the Constitution and section 4 of the twentieth
2 article of amendment to the Constitution.
3

"SEC.

4. This article shall take effect on the first day of

4 July following its ratification, but shall be inoperative unless
5 it shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Constitu6 tion by the legislatures of three-fourths of the States within
7 seven years from the date of its submission to the States by

of the United States for at least 20 years, to be eligible

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 87 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States regarding citizenship in the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 87

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States regarding
citizenship in the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MAY 3, 1995
Mr. STOCKMAN (for himself, Mr. JONES, Mr. FUNDERBURK, Mrs.
CHENOWETH, Mr. BURTON of Indiana, and Mr. SALMON) introduced the
following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the
Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States regarding citizenship in the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with8 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica9 tion:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Citizens of the United States shall only

3 be persons born to a parent who is a citizen of the United
4 States, persons born within the United States and to a
5 parent who was lawfully present in and subject to the ju6 risdiction of the United States at the time of that parent’s
7 entry into the United States, and all persons naturalized
8 according to the laws of the United States.
9

‘‘SECTION 2. Nothing in this Constitution shall re-

10 quire either the Congress or the States to provide pay11 ments or services to any person who is not a citizen of
12 the United States.
13

‘‘SECTION 3. No person shall become a naturalized

14 citizen of the United States who is not conversant in the
15 English language, except for persons under the age of five,
16 and who has not sworn allegiance to the United States
17 over and above allegiance to any other polity.
18

‘‘SECTION 4. Representatives shall be apportioned

19 among the several States according to their respective
20 numbers, counting only the number of citizens of each
21 State.’’.

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget of the United
States Government.

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 167 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for balanced budgets for the United States Government.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 167

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for balanced budgets for the United States Government.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 30, 1993
Mr. DOOLITTLE (for himself, Mr. CONDIT, Mr. COBLE, Mr. YOUNG of Alaska,
Mr. BAKER of Louisiana, Mr. BAKER of California, Mr. ROYCE, Mr. SENSENBRENNER, Mr. ARMEY, Mr. ROHRABACHER, Mr. PAXON, Mr. KLUG,
Mr. ZELIFF, Mr. SANTORUM, Mr. POMBO, Mr. CUNNINGHAM, Mr.
GALLEGLY, Mr. KIM, Mrs. VUCANOVICH, Mr. SMITH of New Jersey, Mr.
GILCHREST, Mr. INGLIS of South Carolina, Mr. HOBSON, Mr. GOSS, Mr.
MCINNIS, Mr. BUYER, Mr. LIVINGSTON, Mr. CRANE, Mr. PACKARD, Mr.
DELAY, Mr. DICKEY, Mr. BURTON of Indiana, Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland, Mr. BOEHNER, Mr. EWING, Mr. FAWELL, Ms. ROS-LEHTINEN, Mr.
STUMP, Ms. PRYCE of Ohio, Mr. STEARNS, Mr. SUNDQUIST, Mr.
TORKILDSEN, Mr. UPTON, Mr. ZIMMER, Mr. LEWIS of Florida, Mr.
FRANKS of Connecticut, Mr. FRANKS of New Jersey, Mrs. FOWLER, Mr.
GALLO, Mr. GEKAS, Mr. GILLMOR, Mr. GINGRICH, Mr. GOODLATTE, Mr.
GRAMS, Mr. GREENWOOD, Mr. HANCOCK, Mr. HANSEN, Mr. HASTERT,
Mr. HEFLEY, Mr. HERGER, Mr. HOEKSTRA, Mr. HOKE, Mr. HORN, Mr.
HUFFINGTON, Mr. HUNTER, Mr. HUTCHINSON, Mr. HYDE, Mr. INHOFE,
Mr. ISTOOK, Mr. SAM JOHNSON of Texas, Mrs. JOHNSON of Connecticut,
and Mr. KASICH) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United

2
States to provide for balanced budgets for the United
States Government.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years after the date of its submission
9 for ratification:
10
11

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays of the United States for

12 any fiscal year shall not exceed total receipts to the United
13 States for that year, unless 3⁄5 of the whole number of
14 both Houses of Congress shall provide for a specific excess
15 of outlays over receipts.
16

‘‘SECTION 2. Any bill for raising taxes shall become

17 law only if approved by a majority of the whole number
18 of both Houses of Congress by rollcall vote.
19

‘‘SECTION 3. The Congress may waive the provisions

20 of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration
21 of war is in effect.
22

‘‘SECTION 4. Total receipts shall include all receipts

23 of the United States except those derived from borrowing.

•HJ 167 IH

3
1 Total outlays shall include all outlays of the United States
2 except for those for repayment of debt principal.
3

‘‘SECTION 5. The limit on the debt of the United

4 States held by the public shall not be increased unless 3⁄5
5 of the whole number of each House shall provide by law
6 for such an increase by a rollcall vote.
7

‘‘SECTION 6. Congress shall enforce this Article by

8 appropriate legislation.
9

‘‘SECTION 7. Except with respect to section 5 which

10 shall take effect upon ratification, this Article shall take
11 effect beginning with fiscal year 1998 or with the second
12 fiscal year beginning after the ratification, whichever is
13 later.’’.

Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 60 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen on account of birth in the United States unless a parent is a United States citizen at the time of the birth.
TEXT_Content:
IA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 60

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
that no person born in the United States will be a United States
citizen on account of birth in the United States unless a parent is
a United States citizen at the time of the birth.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 6, 1997
Mr. CALLAHAN (for himself, Mr. STUMP, Mr. EVERETT, and Mr. TRAFICANT)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen on account of
birth in the United States unless a parent is a United
States citizen at the time of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 to the States for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

5 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
6 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
7 of birth in the United States unless the mother or father
8 of the person is a citizen of the United States at the time
9 of the birth.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

11 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 101 H.R. 364 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: A BILL Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that appropriations made by the United States shall not exceed its revenues, except in time of war or national emergency; and to provide for the systematic paying back of the national debt.
TEXT_Content:
101ST CONGBESS
1ST SESSION

H. R. 364

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that
appropriations made by the United States shall not exceed its revenues,
except in time of war or national emergency; and to provide for the
systematic paying back of the national debt.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
3, 1989
introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee
on the Judiciary
JANUAEY

Mr.

SHUMWAY

A BILL
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution
States to provide that appropriations made
States shall not exceed its revenues, except
or national emergency; and to provide for

of the United
by the United
in time of war
the systematic

paying back of the national debt.
1

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa-

2 tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 That the following article is proposed as an amendment to
4 the Constitution of the United States, to be valid only if rati5 fied by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
6 within seven years after the date of final passage of this joint
7 resolution:

2
1
2

"AKTICLE
"SECTION

—

1. Except as provided in section 2, the Congress

3 shall make no appropriation for any fiscal year if the resulting
4 total of appropriations for such fiscal year would exceed the
5 total estimated revenues of the United States for such fiscal
6 year.
7

"SECTION

2. In time of war or national emergency, as

8 declared by Congress, the application of section 1 may he
9 suspended by a concurrent resolution which has passed the
10 Senate and House of Representatives by an affirmative vote
11 of three-fourths of the authorized membership of each such
12 House. Such suspension shall be effective only for the two13 year term of the Congress which passes such resolution.
14

"SECTION

3. There shall be no increase in the national

15 debt and such debt, as it exists on the date on which this
16 article is ratified, shall be repaid during the one-hundred-year
17 period beginning with the first fiscal year which begins after
18 the date on which this article is ratified. The rate of repay19 ment shall be such that one-tenth of such debt shall be repaid
20 during each ten-year interval of such one-hundred-year
21 period.
22

"SECTION

4. This article shall apply only with respect

23 to fiscal years which begin more than six months after the
24 date on which this article is ratified.".
O

2. The Congress shall have power to enforce

4 this article by appropriate legislation.
5

"SECTION

3. The misuse or desecration of the symbol,

6 emblem, seal, or flag of the several States is not protected
7 speech under the first amendment to the Constitution of the
8 United States.
9

"SECTION

4. The legislatures of the several States shall

10 have power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 105 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give citizens of the United States the right to recall elected officials.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 105

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give
citizens of the United States the right to recall elected officials.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. HOEKSTRA

JULY 26, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to give citizens of the United States the right
to recall elected officials.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with8 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica9 tion:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people shall have the right to recall

3 any person elected by popular vote or the electors of the
4 various States to hold an office of the Federal Govern5 ment.
6

‘‘SECTION 2. A petition proposing the recall of an

7 elected official shall be submitted to an officer of the Gov8 ernment of the United States whom the Congress shall
9 designate by law. Each petition shall be signed by at least
10 ten percent of the whole number of people voting in a
11 given State or congressional district, who voted in the
12 most recent election for President, or for electors for
13 President, occurring before the date on which the petition
14 is submitted to the officer designated by Congress. All
15 such signatures shall be collected within the nine-month
16 period ending on the date the petition is submitted to the
17 officer designated by the Congress. All such signatures
18 shall be collected within the nine-month period ending on
19 the date the petition is submitted to the officer designated
20 by the Congress.
21

‘‘Within ninety days after a petition is submitted to

22 the officer designated by the Congress, such officer shall
23 determine the validity of the signatures contained in the
24 petition. If the petition contains the required number of
25 valid signatures, the officer shall certify the petition and
•HJ 105 IH

3
1 shall direct the chief executive officer in each State to
2 place on a ballot the question of recall before the voters
3 in the State or congressional district for Members of Con4 gress. The Congress shall by law establish procedures for
5 the preparation and submission of any such petition and
6 for the validation of signatures on such petition.
7

‘‘SECTION 3. For the recall of Members of the Senate

8 the recall election shall be held on the first election for
9 Member of the House of Representatives which is held at
10 least sixty days after such direction.
11

‘‘For the recall of Members of the House of Rep-

12 resentatives, a special election shall be ordered within sixty
13 days of the certification of valid signatures on such a peti14 tion.
15

‘‘SECTION 4. If a recall ballot under this article re-

16 ceives a majority of the votes cast in either the district
17 or State of Members of Congress, the recall of the said
18 elected official shall take effect immediately upon certifi19 cation of vote results by the chief executive officer of the
20 States.
21

‘‘SECTION 5. In the event of the removal of a Member

22 of Congress by recall, the chief executive officer of each
23 of the States shall order a special election within the
24 guidelines of the said State.

•HJ 105 IH

4
1

‘‘SECTION 6. The people in each State voting under

2 this Article shall have the qualification requisite for elec3 tors of the most numerous branch of the State legislature.
4 The Congress shall by law prescribe the manner in which
5 the results of the voting conducted under this article shall
6 be ascertained and declared.’’.

Æ

by conventions in the several States, as provided in the

8

Constitution, within seven years from the date of the sub-

9

mission hereof to the States by the Congress."

EDWIN P. THA YER,

IA

102D CONGEESS
1ST SESSION

H.J.RES.81

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States establishing
English as the official language of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
18, 1991
Mr. DICKINSON (for himself, Mr. APPLBGATE, Mr. AEMEY, Mr. BALLENGEE, Mr.
BAETON of Texas, Mrs. BENTLEY, Mr. BEBETJTEE, Mr. BEVILL, Mr. BILIEAKIS, Mr. BLILEY, Mr. BEOOMPIELD, Mr. BUNNING, Mr. EMEESON, Mr.
FAWELL, Mr. GTALLO, Mr. HANSEN, Mr. HEEGEE, Mr. HUTTO, Mr. IRELAND, Mr. JONES of North Carolina, Mr. LIPINSKI, Mr. MCCOLLUM, Mr.
MILLEE of Ohio, Mr. MONTGOMEEY, Mr. POETEE, Mr. QUILLEN, Mr. RAVENEL, Mr. SLAUGHTEE of Virginia, Mr. SPENCE, Mr. STUMP, and Mr.
WALSH) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary
JANUAEY

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States establishing English as the official language of the
United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein),
4
5

"AETICLB
"SECTION

—

1. The English language shall be the official

6 language of the United States.

1

"SECTION

2. Neither the United States nor any State

2 shall require, by law, ordinance, regulation, order, decree,
3 program, or policy, the use in the United States of any lan4 guage other than English.
5

"SECTION

3. This article shall not prohibit any law,

6 ordinance, regulation, order, decree, program, or policy—
7

"(1) to provide educational instruction in a lan-

8

guage other than English for the purpose of making

9

students who use a language other than English profi-

10

cient in English,

11
12

"(2) to teach a foreign language to students who
already are proficient in English,

13

"(3) to protect public health and safety, or

14

"(4) to allow translators for litigants, defendants,

15

or witnesses in court cases.

16

"SECTION

4. The Congress and the States may enforce

17 this article by appropriate legislation.".
O

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 340 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born to parents who are unlawfully in the United States at the time of the birth shall be a United States citizen on account of birth in the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 340

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
that no person born to parents who are unlawfully in the United States
at the time of the birth shall be a United States citizen on account
of birth in the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 16, 1994
Mr. TAYLOR of North Carolina (for himself and Mr. SOLOMON) introduced the
following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the
Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born to parents who
are unlawfully in the United States at the time of the
birth shall be a United States citizen on account of
birth in the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-

2
1 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
2 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
3 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
4 States within seven years after the date of its submission
5 to the States for ratification:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

8 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
9 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
10 of birth in the United States unless the mother or father
11 of the person is a citizen of the United States, is lawfully
12 in the United States, or has a lawful status under the im13 migration laws of the United States, at the time of the
14 birth.
15

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

16 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States authorizing the Congress and the States to prohibit
the physical desecration of the flag of the United States.
Whereas the flag of the United States of America is a national
symbol of such stature that it must be kept inviolate;
Whereas the physical desecration of the flag should not be considered constitutionally protected speech; and
Whereas physical desecration may include, but is not limited to,
such acts as burning, mutilating, defacing, defiling or trampling on the flag, or displaying the flag in a contemptuous

Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 87 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give citizens of the United States the right to enact and repeal laws by voting on legislation in a national election.
TEXT_Content:
IA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 87

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give
citizens of the United States the right to enact and repeal laws by
voting on legislation in a national election.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. HOEKSTRA

JUNE 25, 1997
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to give citizens of the United States the right
to enact and repeal laws by voting on legislation in
a national election.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with-

2
1 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica2 tion:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people shall have the right to enact

5 any law which the Congress has authority to pass, and
6 to repeal any provision of law passed by Congress which
7 has become law, except that the people shall not have the
8 right to declare war, grant letters of marque and reprisal,
9 make rules concerning captures on land and water, or call
10 forth the militia.
11

‘‘SECTION 2. A petition proposing the enactment of

12 a law, or the repeal of a provision of law, shall be submit13 ted to an officer of the Government of the United States
14 whom the Congress shall designate by law. Each petition
15 shall contain the text of the proposed law, or, in the case
16 of a proposed repeal of a provision of law, the text of the
17 provision of law that shall cease to be effective if repealed
18 under this article. Each petition shall be signed by at least
19 3 percent of the whole number of people, in each of at
20 least 10 States, who voted in the most recent election for
21 President, or for electors for President, occurring before
22 the date on which the petition is submitted to the officer
23 designated by Congress, and the total number of signa24 tures on such petition shall be at least 3 percent of the
25 whole number of people, from all of the several States,
•HJ 87 IH

3
1 who voted in such election. All such signatures shall be
2 collected within the 18-month period ending on the date
3 the petition is submitted to the officer designated by the
4 Congress.
5

‘‘Within 90 days after a petition is submitted to the

6 officer designated by the Congress, such officer shall de7 termine the validity of the signatures contained in the pe8 tition. If the petition contains the required number of valid
9 signatures, the officer shall certify the petition and shall
10 direct the chief executive officer in each State to place a
11 copy of the proposed law, or provision of law proposed to
12 be repealed, contained in the petition on the ballot in the
13 first election (other than an election to fill a vacancy) for
14 Members of the House of Representatives which is held
15 at least 120 days after such certification. The Congress
16 shall by law establish procedures for the preparation and
17 submission of any such petition and for the validation of
18 signatures on such petition.
19

‘‘SECTION 3. If a law or repeal proposed under this

20 article receives a majority of the votes cast in three-fifths
21 of the several States, the proposed law or repeal shall be
22 introduced to the Congress by the Speaker of the House
23 of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the
24 Senate on the first day of the first session of Congress
25 following the vote.
•HJ 87 IH

4
1

‘‘If Congress does not enact the proposed law or re-

2 peal, without amendment, before the end of one year and
3 90 days after the first day of the first session of Congress
4 following the vote, the officer to whom the petition was
5 submitted shall direct the chief executive officer in each
6 State again to place a copy of the proposed law, or provi7 sion of law proposed to be repealed, contained in the peti8 tion, together with any amended version approved by Con9 gress, on the ballot in the first election (other than an
10 election to fill a vacancy) for Members of the House of
11 Representatives which is held at least 120 days after such
12 direction.
13

‘‘If a law or repeal again placed on the ballot pursu-

14 ant to this article receives a majority of the votes cast
15 in three-fifths of the several States, the proposed law or
16 repeal shall be enacted and take effect according to its
17 terms.
18

‘‘No law, or repeal of a provision of law, which is en-

19 acted under this article shall be subject to approval of the
20 President.
21

‘‘The Congress may not, during the 2-year period be-

22 ginning on the date on which a law enacted by the people
23 under this article takes effect, or the date on which a law
24 repealed by the people under this article ceases to be effec25 tive, repeal or amend a law so enacted, or reenact any
•HJ 87 IH

5
1 part of a law so repealed, except by an affirmative vote
2 of two-thirds of the Members of each House of Congress.
3

‘‘SECTION 4. The people in each State voting under

4 this article shall have the qualification requisite for elec5 tors of the most numerous branch of the State legislature.
6 The Congress shall by law prescribe the manner in which
7 the results of the voting conducted under this article shall
8 be ascertained and declared.’’.

Æ

•HJ 87 IH

Title:: 51 H. Res. 24 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States providing for the election of Senators by the votes of the people of the States.
TEXT_Content:
1ST SESSION.

H. RES. 24.

IN THE HOUSE OF BEPBJB8ENTATIVES.
DECEMBER

18,1889.

Bead twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed.

Mr. HERMANN introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
providing for the election of Senators by the votes of the people
of the States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment to the Constitution of the United States

5

be proposed to the legislatures of the several States; which,

6

when ratified by three-fourths of said legislatures, shall be-

7

come and be a part of the Constitution, namely :

8

Strike out the word ''legislature" in the first clause of

9

section three of Article I, and substitute in lieu thereof the

10

word " people;" so that said clause shall read as follows:

11

"The Senate of the United States shall be composed of

12

two Senators from each State, chosen by the people thereof

13

for six years; and each Senator shall have one vote."

Title:: 102 H. J. Res. 93 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States limiting the number of consecutive terms members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives may serve.
TEXT_Content:
IA

102D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 93

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States limiting the
number of consecutive terms members of the United States Senate and
House of Representatives may serve.

IN THE HOUSE OF KEPEESENTATIVES
28, 1991
Mr. DOENAN of California introduced the following joint resolution; which was
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary
JANUARY

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States limiting the number of consecutive terms members of
the United States Senate and House of Eepresentatives
may serve.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by the
7 legislatures of three-fourths of the several States within
8 seven years after the date of its submission for ratification:

2
1
2

"ABTICLE
"SECTION

—

1. No person may serve any term or portion

3 thereof as a member of the United States House of Eepre4 sentatives if such person has served as a member of the
5 ID se for each of the six terms, or a portion of any such
6 ctrm, immediately preceding such term.
7

"SECTION

2. No person may serve any term or portion

8 thereof as a member of the United States Senate if such
9 person has served as a member of the Senate for each of the
10 two terms, or a portion of any such term, immediately pre11 ceding such term.
12

"SECTION

3. For purposes of this article, service as a

13 member in the United States Senate or House of Eepresenta14 tives in any term which commenced before the ratification of
15 this article may not be included in determining the number of
16 terms served.".

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 123 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for a balanced budget for the United States Government.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 123

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for a balanced budget for the United States Government.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. ORTON

FEBRUARY 24, 1993
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget for the United
States Government.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if ratified
7 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States

2
1 within seven years after its submission to the States for
2 ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays of the United States for

5 any fiscal year shall not exceed total receipts to the United
6 States for that fiscal year.
7

‘‘SECTION 2. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

8 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
9 United States Government for that fiscal year in which
10 total outlays do not exceed total receipts.
11

‘‘SECTION 3. For any fiscal year in which actual out-

12 lays exceed actual receipts, the Congress shall provide by
13 law for the repayment in the ensuing fiscal year of such
14 excess outlays. If Congress fails to provide by law for re15 payment, within fifteen days after Congress adjourns to
16 end a session, there shall be a sequestration of all outlays
17 to eliminate a budget deficit.
18

‘‘SECTION 4. The provisions of this article may be

19 waived for any fiscal year only if Congress so provides by
20 law by a majority of the whole number of each House.
21 Such waiver shall be subject to veto by the President.
22

‘‘SECTION 5. Total receipts shall include all receipts

23 of the United States Government except those derived
24 from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of

HJ 123 IH

3
1 the United States Government, except for those for repay2 ment of debt principal.
3

‘‘SECTION 6. This article shall take effect beginning

4 with fiscal year 2000 or with the second fiscal year begin5 ning after its ratification, whichever is later.’’.
Æ

HJ 123 IH

Title:: 108 H. J. Res. 104 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to make eligible for the Office of President a person who is not a natural born citizen of the United States but has been a United States citizen for at least 20 years.
TEXT_Content:
IA

108TH CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 104

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to make
eligible for the Office of President a person who is not a natural born
citizen of the United States but has been a United States citizen for
at least 20 years.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
SEPTEMBER 15, 2004
Mr. ROHRABACHER introduced the following joint resolution; which was
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to make eligible for the Office of President a
person who is not a natural born citizen of the United
States but has been a United States citizen for at least
20 years.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘A person who is a citizen of the United States, who

5 has been a citizen of the United States for at least 20
6 years, and who is otherwise eligible to hold the Office of
7 the President, is not ineligible to hold that Office by rea8 son of not being a native born citizen of the United
9 States.’’.

IA

English as the official language of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
SEPTEMBER 28, 1995
Mr. DOOLITTLE (for himself, Mr. HANCOCK, Mr. HANSEN, and Mr. SHAYS)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States establishing English as the official language of
the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The English language shall be the offi-

5 cial language of the United States. As the official lan6 guage, the English language shall be used for all public
7 acts including every order, resolution, vote or election, and
8 for all records and judicial proceedings of the Government
9 of the United States and the governments of the several
10 States.
11

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress and the States shall en-

12 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 26 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, is lawfully in the United States, or has a lawful immigration status at the time of the birth.
TEXT_Content:
IA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 26

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
that no person born in the United States will be a United States
citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, is lawfully in the
United States, or has a lawful immigration status at the time of the
birth.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 9, 1997
Mr. FOLEY (for himself, Mr. ROHRABACHER, Mr. ROYCE, Mr. DOOLITTLE,
YOUNG of Alaska, Mrs. CHENOWETH, Mr. MCKEON, Mr. CALVERT, Mr.
KLUG, Mr. BAKER of Louisiana, and Mr. METCALF) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen unless a parent
is a United States citizen, is lawfully in the United
States, or has a lawful immigration status at the time
of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two-

2
1 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow2 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu3 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
4 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
5 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with6 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica7 tion:
8
9

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

10 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
11 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
12 of birth in the United States unless the mother or father
13 of the person is a citizen of the United States, is lawfully
14 in the United States, or has a lawful status under the im15 migration laws of the United States, at the time of the
16 birth.
17

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

18 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Æ

Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 4 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen on account of birth in the United States unless both parents are either United States citizens or aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence at the time of the birth.

IA

Mr. BARR

JANUARY 7, 1997
of Georgia introduced the following joint resolution; which was
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen on account of
birth in the United States unless both parents are either
United States citizens or aliens lawfully admitted for
permanent residence at the time of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

6 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
7 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
8 of birth in the United States unless the mother and father
9 of the person are either citizens of the United States or
10 aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence at the
11 time of the birth.
12

‘‘SEC. 2. The Congress shall have power to enforce

13 this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

MAY 26 (legislative day, MAY 15), 1995

resolution; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the
Judiciary

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to allow the States to limit the period of time

5 Constitution of the United States:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Each State or the people thereof may

8 prescribe the maximum number of terms to which a per-

2
1 son may be elected or appointed to the Senate of the
2 United States.

4 prescribe the maximum number of terms to which a per5 son may be elected to the House of Representatives of the

8 it shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Con9 stitution by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
10 States within seven years from the date of its submission
11 to the States by the Congress.’’.

IA

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for a balanced budget for the United States Government.

9, 1992
Mr. ORTON (for himself and Mr. Cox of Illinois) introduced the following joint
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary
JUNE

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget for the United
States Government.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if ratified
7 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States

1 within seven years after its submission to the States for
2 ratification:
3
4

"ARTICLE—
"SECTION

1. Total outlays of the United States for

5 any fiscal year shall not exceed total receipts to the United
6 States for that fiscal year.
7

"SECTION 2. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

8 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
9 United States Government for that fiscal year in which
10 total outlays do not exceed total receipts.
11

"SECTION

3. For any fiscal year in which actual out-

12 lays exceed actual receipts, the Congress shall provide by
13 law for the repayment in the ensuing fiscal year of such
14 excess outlays. If Congress fails to provide by law for re15 payment, within fifteen days after Congress adjourns to
16 end a session, there shall be a sequestration of all outlays
17 to eliminate a budget deficit.
18

"SECTION

4. The provisions of this article may be

19 waived for any fiscal year only if Congress so provides by
20 law by a majority of the whole number of each House on
21 a roll call vote. Such waiver shall be subject to veto by
22 the President.
23

"SECTION

5. Total receipts shall include all receipts

24 of the United States Government except those derived
25 from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of

1 the United States Government except for those for repay2 ment of principal and interest on debt incurred prior to
3 ratification of this article. Principal and interest payments
4 on public debt which is incurred after ratification of this

6

"SECTION

6. This article shall take effect beginning
