TEXT_Content:
IA

101ST CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 450

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to permit
certain naturalized citizens of the United States to hold the offices of
President and Vice President.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
21, 1989
introduced the following joint lesolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judioiarv
NOVEMBEP

Mr.

FAZIO

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to permit certain naturalized citizens of the United
States to hold the offices of President and Vice President.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by the
7 legislatures of three-fourths of the several States within
8 seven years after the date of its submission for ratification.

2

—

"A person who is a naturalized citizen of the United

3 States and who is otherwise eligible to hold the office of the

Title:: 101 H. J. Res. 61 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: H. J. RES. 61 Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that appropriations made by the United States shall not exceed its revenues, except in time of war or threat of war as determined by the Congress; and to provide for the systematic paying back of the national debt.
TEXT_Content:
IA

101ST CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H.J.RES.61

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that
appropriations made by the United States shall not exceed its revenues,
except in time of war or threat of war as determined by the Congress; and to
provide for the systematic paying back of the national debt.

N THE HOUSE OP REPRESENTATIVES
3, 1989
Mr. QUILLEN introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary
JANUARY

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that appropriations made by the United
States shall not exceed its revenues, except in time of war
or threat of war as determined by the Congress; ind to
provide for the systematic paying back of the national debt.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of

2 the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), Tha

lie following

4 article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitution of
5 the United States, to be valid only if ratified by the legisla6 tures of three-fourths of the several States within seven years
7 from the date of its submission to the States by the Congress:

2
1
2

'ARTICLE
"SECTION

—

1. Except as provided in section 2, the Con-

3 gress shall make no appropriations for any fiscal year if the
4 resulting total of appropriations for such fiscal year would
5 exceed the total estimated revenues of the United States for
6 such fiscal year.
7

"SECTION

2. In time of war or threat of war, as deter-

8 mined by the Congress, the application 'A section 1 may be
9 suspended by a concurrent resolution which has passed the
10 Senate and the House of Representatives by an affirmative
11 vote of three-fourths of each such House. Such suspension
12 shall be effective only for the two-year term of the Congress
13 which passes such resolution.
14

"SECTION

3. There shall be no increase in the national

15 debt and such debt, as it exists on the date on which this
16 article is ratified, shall be repaid during the one-hundred-year
17 period beginning with the first fiscal year which begins after
18 the date on which this article is ratified. The rate of repay19 ment shall be such that one-tenth of such debt shall be repaid
20 during each ten-year interval of such one-hundred-year
21 period.
22

"SECTION

4. This article shall apply only with respect

23 to fiscal years which begin more than six months after the
24 date on which this article is ratified.".

Title:: 109 H. J. Res. 41 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States, at the time of the birth.
TEXT_Content:
IA

109TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 41

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
that no person born in the United States will be a United States
citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted
for permanent residence in the United States, at the time of the birth.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 13, 2005
Mr. FOLEY (for himself, Mr. SHAYS, and Ms. FOXX) introduced the following
joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen unless a parent
is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted for
permanent residence in the United States, at the time
of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

6 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be
7 a citizen of the United States, or of any State, on account
8 of birth in the United States unless the mother or father
9 of the person is a citizen of the United States, or is law10 fully admitted for permanent residence in the United
11 States, at the time of the birth.

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

13 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 109 H. J. Res. 46 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to deny United States citizenship to individuals born in the United States to parents who are neither United States citizens nor persons who owe permanent allegiance to the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

109TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 46

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to deny
United States citizenship to individuals born in the United States to
parents who are neither United States citizens nor persons who owe
permanent allegiance to the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 28, 2005
Mr. PAUL (for himself and Mr. ALEXANDER) introduced the following joint
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to deny United States citizenship to individuals
born in the United States to parents who are neither
United States citizens nor persons who owe permanent
allegiance to the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Any person born after the date of the

5 ratification of this article to a mother and father, neither
6 of whom is a citizen of the United States nor a person
7 who owes permanent allegiance to the United States, shall
8 not be a citizen of the United States or of any State solely
9 by reason of birth in the United States.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

11 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

4
5

"AETICLE
"SECTION

—

1. The English language shall be the official

6 language of the United States.

2
1

"SECTION

2. Neither the United States nor any State

2 shall require, by law, ordinance, regulation, order, decree,

"SECTION

6 ordinance, regulation, order, decree, program, or policy—

guage other than English for the purpose of making

students who use a language other than English profi-

cient in English,

are already proficient in English,

"(3) to protect public health and safety, or

15

or witnesses in court cases.

16

"SECTION

4. The Congress and the States may enforce

17 this article by appropriate legislation.".

Title:: 108 H. J. Res. 42 (Introduced in the House)

IA

1ST SESSION

parents who are neither United States citizens nor persons who owe
permanent allegiance to the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 20, 2003
Mr. PAUL (for himself, Mr. DUNCAN, Mr. TANCREDO, and Mr. GOODE) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee
on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to deny United States citizenship to individuals
born in the United States to parents who are neither
United States citizens nor persons who owe permanent
allegiance to the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Any person born after the date of the

5 ratification of this article to a mother and father, neither
6 of whom is a citizen of the United States nor a person
7 who owes permanent allegiance to the United States, shall
8 not be a citizen of the United States or of any State solely
9 by reason of birth in the United States.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

11 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 103 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give citizens of the United States the right to enact and repeal laws by voting on legislation in a national election.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 103

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to give
citizens of the United States the right to enact and repeal laws by
voting on legislation in a national election.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. HOEKSTRA

JULY 26, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to give citizens of the United States the right
to enact and repeal laws by voting on legislation in
a national election.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with-

2
1 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica2 tion:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people shall have the right to enact

5 any law which the Congress has authority to pass, and
6 to repeal any provision of law passed by Congress which
7 has become law, except that the people shall not have the
8 right to declare war, grant letters of marque and reprisal,
9 make rules concerning captures on land and water, or call
10 forth the militia.
11

‘‘SECTION 2. A petition proposing the enactment of

12 a law, or the repeal of a provision of law, shall be submit13 ted to an officer of the Government of the United States
14 whom the Congress shall designate by law. Each petition
15 shall contain the text of the proposed law, or, in the case
16 of a proposed repeal of a provision of law, the text of the
17 provision of law that shall cease to be effective if repealed
18 under this article. Each petition shall be signed by at least
19 3 percent of the whole number of people, in each of at
20 least 10 States, who voted in the most recent election for
21 President, or for electors for President, occurring before
22 the date on which the petition is submitted to the officer
23 designated by Congress, and the total number of signa24 tures on such petition shall be at least 3 percent of the
25 whole number of people, from all of the several States,
•HJ 103 IH

3
1 who voted in such election. All such signatures shall be
2 collected within the 18-month period ending on the date
3 the petition is submitted to the officer designated by the
4 Congress.
5

‘‘Within 90 days after a petition is submitted to the

6 officer designated by the Congress, such officer shall de7 termine the validity of the signatures contained in the pe8 tition. If the petition contains the required number of valid
9 signatures, the officer shall certify the petition and shall
10 direct the chief executive officer in each State to place a
11 copy of the proposed law, or provision of law proposed to
12 be repealed, contained in the petition on the ballot in the
13 first election (other than an election to fill a vacancy) for
14 Members of the House of Representatives which is held
15 at least 120 days after such certification. The Congress
16 shall by law establish procedures for the preparation and
17 submission of any such petition and for the validation of
18 signatures on such petition.
19

‘‘SECTION 3. If a law or repeal proposed under this

20 article receives a majority of the votes cast in three-fifths
21 of the several States, the proposed law or repeal shall be
22 introduced to the Congress by the Speaker of the House
23 of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the
24 Senate on the first day of the first session of Congress
25 following the vote.
•HJ 103 IH

4
1

‘‘If Congress does not enact the proposed law or re-

2 peal, without amendment, before the end of one year and
3 90 days after the first day of the first session of Congress
4 following the vote, the officer to whom the petition was
5 submitted shall direct the chief executive officer in each
6 State again to place a copy of the proposed law, or provi7 sion of law proposed to be repealed, contained in the peti8 tion, together with any amended version approved by Con9 gress, on the ballot in the first election (other than an
10 election to fill a vacancy) for Members of the House of
11 Representatives which is held at least 120 days after such
12 direction.
13

‘‘If a law or repeal again placed on the ballot pursu-

14 ant to this article receives a majority of the votes cast
15 in three-fifths of the several States, the proposed law or
16 repeal shall be enacted and take effect according to its
17 terms.
18

‘‘No law, or repeal of a provision of law, which is en-

19 acted under this article shall be subject to approval of the
20 President.
21

‘‘The Congress may not, during the 2-year period be-

22 ginning on the date on which a law enacted by the people
23 under this article takes effect, or the date on which a law
24 repealed by the people under this article ceases to be effec25 tive, repeal or amend a law so enacted, or reenact any
•HJ 103 IH

5
1 part of a law so repealed, except by an affirmative vote
2 of two-thirds of the Members of each House of Congress.
3

‘‘SECTION 4. The people in each State voting under

4 this article shall have the qualification requisite for elec5 tors of the most numerous branch of the State legislature.
6 The Congress shall by law prescribe the manner in which
7 the results of the voting conducted under this article shall
8 be ascertained and declared.’’.

Æ

•HJ 103 IH

Title:: 106 S. J. Res. 45 (Introduced in the Senate)

IIA

2D SESSION

S. J. RES. 45

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to allow
the States to limit the period of time United States Senators and Representatives may serve.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
APRIL 13, 2000
Mr. ASHCROFT introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice
and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to allow the States to limit the period of time
United States Senators and Representatives may serve.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is hereby proposed as an amendment to the
5 Constitution of the United States:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Each State or the people thereof may

8 prescribe the maximum number of terms to which a per-

2
1 son may be elected or appointed to the Senate of the
2 United States.
3

‘‘SECTION 2. Each State or the people thereof may

4 prescribe the maximum number of terms to which a per5 son may be elected to the House of Representatives of the
6 United States.
7

‘‘SECTION 3. This article shall be inoperative unless

8 it shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Con9 stitution by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
10 States within seven years from the date of its submission
11 to the States by the Congress.’’.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 46 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for a balanced budget for the United States Government and for greater accountability in the enactment of tax legislation and to allow an item veto of appropriation bills.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 46

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for a balanced budget for the United States Government and for greater
accountability in the enactment of tax legislation and to allow an item
veto of appropriation bills.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. ZIMMER

JANUARY 4, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget for the United
States Government and for greater accountability in the
enactment of tax legislation and to allow an item veto
of appropriation bills.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid in all

2
1 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if ratified
2 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
3 within seven years after its submission to the States for
4 ratification:
5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Prior to each fiscal year, the Congress

7 and the President shall agree on an estimate of total re8 ceipts for that fiscal year by enactment into law of a joint
9 resolution devoted soley to that subject. Total outlays for
10 that year shall not exceed the level of estimated receipts
11 set forth in such joint resolution, unless two-thirds of the
12 total membership of each House of Congress shall provide,
13 by a rollcall vote, for a specific excess of outlays over esti14 mated receipts.
15

‘‘SECTION 2. The public debt of the United States

16 shall not be increased unless two-thirds of the total mem17 bership of each House shall provide by law for such an
18 increase by a rollcall vote.
19

‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

20 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
21 United States Government for that fiscal year in which
22 total outlays do not exceed total receipts.
23

‘‘SECTION 4. No bill to increase revenue shall become

24 law unless approved by two-thirds of the total membership
25 of each House by a rollcall vote.

HJ 46 IH

3
1

‘‘SECTION 5. The provisions of this article are waived

2 for any fiscal year in which a declaration of war is in ef3 fect.
4

‘‘SECTION 6. Total receipts shall include all receipts

5 of the United States except those derived from borrowing.
6 Total outlays shall include all outlays of the United States
7 except for those for repayment of the debt principal.
8

‘‘SECTION 7. The President shall have the power to

9 disapprove any appropriation or provision and approve any
10 other appropriation or provision in the same appropriation
11 bill. In such case he shall, in signing the bill, designate
12 the appropriations and provisions disapproved, and shall
13 return a copy of such appropriations and provisions, with
14 his objections, to the House in which the bill shall have
15 orginated; and the same proceedings shall then be had as
16 in the case of other bills disapproved by the President.
17

‘‘SECTION 8. Sections 1 through 6 of this article shall

18 take effect beginning with the second fiscal year beginning
19 after its ratification and section 7 of this article shall take
20 effect upon ratification.’’.

Æ

HJ 46 IH

liability companies, and other corporate entities established by the laws

19,1991

referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

Mr.

COLEMAN

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that appropriations made by the United
States shall not exceed its revenues, except in time of
war or national emergency; and to provide for the systematic paying back of the national debt.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

"ARTICLE —
"SECTION

1. Except as provided in section 2, the

5 Congress shall make no appropriation for any fiscal year
6 if the resulting total of appropriations for such fiscal year
7 would exceed the total estimated revenues of the United
8 States for such fiscal year.
9

"SECTION

2. In time of war or national emergency,

10 as declared by the Congress, the applications of section
11 1 may be suspended by a concurrent resolution which has
12 passed the Senate and the House of Representatives by
13 an affirmative vote of three-fourths of the authorized
14 membership of each such House. Such suspension shall
15 be effective only for the two-year term of the Congress
16 which passes such resolution.
17

"SECTION

3. There shall be no increase in the na-

18 tional debt and such debt, as it exists on the date on which
19 this article is ratified, shall be repaid during the one-hun20 dred-year period beginning with the first fiscal year which
21 begins after the date on which this article is ratified. The
22 rate of repayment shall be such that one-tenth of such
23 debt shall be repaid during each ten-year interval of such
24 one-hundred-year period.

"SECTION

4. This article shall apply only with respect

2 to fiscal years which begin more than six months after
3 the date on which this article is ratified. >>

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 37 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for a balanced budget for the United States Government.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 37

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for a balanced budget for the United States Government.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. ORTON

JANUARY 4, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for a balanced budget for the United
States Government.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if ratified
7 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
8 within seven years after its submission to the States for
9 ratification:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays of the United States for

3 any fiscal year shall not exceed total receipts to the United
4 States for that fiscal year.
5

‘‘SECTION 2. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

6 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
7 United States Government for that fiscal year in which
8 total outlays do not exceed total receipts.
9

‘‘SECTION 3. For any fiscal year in which actual out-

10 lays exceed actual receipts, the Congress shall provide by
11 law for the repayment in the ensuing fiscal year of such
12 excess outlays. If Congress fails to provide by law for re13 payment, within fifteen days after Congress adjourns to
14 end a session, there shall be a sequestration of all outlays
15 to eliminate a budget deficit.
16

‘‘SECTION 4. The provisions of this article may be

17 waived for any fiscal year only if Congress so provides by
18 law by a majority of the whole number of each House.
19 Such waiver shall be subject to veto by the President.
20

‘‘SECTION 5. Total receipts shall include all receipts

21 of the United States Government except those derived
22 from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of
23 the United States Government, except for those for repay24 ment of debt principal.

HJ 37 IH

3
1

‘‘SECTION 6. This article shall take effect beginning

2 with fiscal year 2002 or with the second fiscal year begin3 ning after its ratification, whichever is later.’’.

Æ

HJ 37 IH

Title:: 71 S.J. Res. 3 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States fixing the commencement of the terms of President and Vice President and Members of Congress and fixing the time of the assembling of Congress.
TEXT_Content:
71ST

CONGRESS

_2» SESSION ___

£!

T

ft% J

"DT7C!

IN THE HOUSE OE REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL

17, 1930

Referred to the Committee on Election of President, Vice President, and
Representatives in Congress

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
fixing the commencement of the terms of President and
Vice President and Members of Congress and fixing the
time of the assembling of Congress.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment of the Constitution be, and hereby is,

5

proposed to the States, to become valid as a part of said

6

Constitution when ratified by the legislatures of the several

7

States as provided by the Constitution:

8
9
10

"ARTICLE
"SECTION

—

1. The terms of the President and Vice

President shall end at noon on the 15th day of January,

1

and the terms of Senators and Representatives at noon on

2

the 2d day of January, of the years in which such

3

terms would have ended If this article had not been ratified;

4

and the terms of their successors shall then begin.

5

" SEC. 2. The Congress shall assemble at least once in

6

every year, and such meeting shall begin at noon on the

7

2d day of January, unless they shall by law appoint a

8

different day.

0

" SEC. 3. If the House of Representatives has not

10

chosen a President? whenever the right of choice devolves

11

upon them, before the time fixed for the beginning of his

12

term, then the Vice President shall act as President, as in

13

the case of the death or other constitutional disability of the

14

President. ' The Congress shall by law provide for the case

15

of the failure to choose the Vice President before the time

16

fixed for the beginning of his term, declaring. what officer

17

shall then act as President, and such officer shall act accord-

18

ingly until the House of Representatives chooses, a President

19

or until the Senate chooses a Vice President.

20
21

" SEC. 4. This amendment shall take effect on the
15th day of October after its ratification."
Passed the Senate June 4 (calendar day, June 7) ,1929.
Attest:

EDWIN P. THAYER,
Secretary.

—

"The Congress and the States shall have power to pro-

11 hibit the physical desecration of the Flag of the United
12 States.".

Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide that no person born in the United States will be a United States citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States, at the time of the birth.
TEXT_Content:
IA

1ST SESSION

that no person born in the United States will be a United States
citizen unless a parent is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

Mr. FOLEY (for himself, Mr. JONES of North Carolina, Mr.
GINNY BROWN-WAITE of Florida, Mr. GOODE, Mr.
SHAYS, Mr. BEREUTER, Mr. DEAL of Georgia, and Mr.
duced the following joint resolution; which was referred
on the Judiciary

DOOLITTLE, Mr.
NORWOOD) introto the Committee

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide that no person born in the United
States will be a United States citizen unless a parent
is a United States citizen, or is lawfully admitted for
permanent residence in the United States, at the time
of the birth.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all

2 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
3 States within seven years after the date of its submission

5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person born in the United States

7 after the date of the ratification of this article shall be

14 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

TEXT_Content:
Calendar No. 1101

H. J. RES. 264
IN THE SENATE OE THE UNITED STATES
October 9,1970
Ordered to be printed as modified

AMENDMENTS
Proprosed by Mr. Allen (for himself and Mr. Thubmond) to

H.J. Res. 264, a joint resolution proposing an amendment
to the Constitution of the United, States relative to equal
rights for men and women, viz:
1

On page 1, line 3, beginning with the word “That”

2 strike out everything down through line 7 and insert in lieu
3 thereof the following: “That the articles set forth in sections
4 2 and 3 of this joint resolution are proposed as amendments

5 to the Constitution of the United States, and either or both
6 articles shall be valid to all intents and purposes as part of

the Constitution if ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths
8 of the several States within seven years after being submitted

y-. hy^-the Congress to the States for ratification.”.

On page 1, between lines 7 and 8, insert the following:
AnsdtNo. 1047

1

“Sec. 2. The first article so proposed is the following:”.

2

On page 2, after line 7, insert the following:

3

“Sec. 3. The second article so proposed is the following:

4

“Article —

5

“A State shall have the absolute right to assign students

6

to the public schools it operates by a freedom of choice sys­

7

tem. A freedom of choice system means a system for the

8

assignment of students to public schools and within public

9

schools maintained by a school board operating a system of

10

public schools hi which the public schools and the classes it

11

operates are open to students of all races, creeds, and national

12

origins, and in which the students are granted the freedom

13

to attend public schools and classes chosen by their respec­

14

tive parents from among the public schools and classes avail­

15

able for the instruction of students of their ages and educa­

16

tional standings.”

fixing the commencement of the terms of President and Vice
President and Members of Congress and fixing the time of

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

their election.

3. That the Congress shall assemble at least once

6

ia every year and such meeting shall be on the first Monday

7

in January, unless they shall by law appoint a different day.

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 129 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to restrict the requirement of citizenship at birth by virtue of birth in the United States to persons with citizen or legal resident mothers.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 129

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to restrict
the requirement of citizenship at birth by virtue of birth in the United
States to persons with citizen or legal resident mothers.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 3, 1993
Mr. GALLEGLY (for himself, Mr. HYDE, Mr. ARCHER, Mr. ROHRABACHER,
Mr. DOOLITTLE, Mr. DUNCAN, Mr. KASICH, Mr. CUNNINGHAM, Mr.
YOUNG of Alaska, Mr. MCCANDLESS, Mr. STUMP, Mr. EMERSON, and
Mr. MCCOLLUM) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to restrict the requirement of citizenship at birth
by virtue of birth in the United States to persons with
citizen or legal resident mothers.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all

2
1 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
2 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
3 States within seven years after the date of its submission
4 for ratification:
5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. All persons born in the United States,

7 and subject to the jurisdiction thereof, of mothers who are
8 citizens or legal residents of the United States and all per9 sons naturalized in the United States are citizens of the
10 United States and of the State wherein they reside. The
11 first sentence of section 1 of the fourteenth article of
12 amendment to the Constitution of the United States is
13 hereby repealed.
14

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

15 force this article by appropriate legislation.
16

‘‘SECTION 3. This article shall apply to persons born

17 after the date of its ratification.’’.

59TH CONGRESS,

IX THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,

Mr. NORRIS introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on Election of President, Vice-President, and Representatives in
Congress and ordered to be printed.
APRIL

11, 1906.

Committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union and
ordered to be printed.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States,
providing for the election and term of office of Members of
Congress.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each JSouse concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment to the Constitution of the United States

5

be proposed to the several States, the same to be valid and

6

to become a part of said Constitution when ratified by the

7

legislatures of three-fourths of said States, namely:

8
9

"ARTICLE
"SECTION

XVI.

1. SENATORS.—Senators shall be elected by

10

the people of the several States for a term of six years.

A

11

plurality of the votes cast for candidates for Senators shall

12

elect, and the qualifications to vote for Senators shall be

1

the same as for Members of the House of Representatives.

2

When vacancies happen by resignation or otherwise in the

3

representation of any State in the Senate, the same shall be

4

filled for the unexpired term thereof, in the same manner as

5

is herein provided for the election of Senators: Provided,

6

That the executive thereof shall make temporary appoint-

7

ment until the next general or special election held in accord-

8

ance with the statutes or constitution of such State: And

9 provided further, That this amendment shall not be con10

strued as vacating the office of any Senator who has been

11

elected prior to its adoption.

12

"SEC.

2. MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTA-

13

TIVES.—The

term of office of Members of the House of.

14

Representatives shall be four years."

Title:: 108 H. J. Res. 48 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect the rights of crime victims.
TEXT_Content:
IA

108TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 48

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect
the rights of crime victims.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 10, 2003
Mr. CHABOT (for himself, Mr. VITTER, Mr. SAXTON, Mr. KENNEDY of Minnesota, Ms. PRYCE of Ohio, Mr. GREEN of Wisconsin, Mr. SHAYS, Mr.
RENZI, Mr. HAYWORTH, Mr. SHADEGG, Mr. BRADY of Texas, Mr.
FOSSELLA, Mr. FLAKE, Mr. WALDEN of Oregon, Mr. ROYCE, and Mr.
GALLEGLY) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to protect the rights of crime victims.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The rights of victims of violent crime,

8 being capable of protection without denying the constitu-

2
1 tional rights of those accused of victimizing them, are
2 hereby established and shall not be denied by any State
3 or the United States and may be restricted only as pro4 vided in this article.
5

‘‘SECTION 2. A victim of violent crime shall have the

6 right to reasonable and timely notice of any public pro7 ceeding involving the crime and of any release or escape
8 of the accused; the rights not to be excluded from such
9 public proceeding and reasonably to be heard at public re10 lease, plea, sentencing, reprieve, and pardon proceedings;
11 and the right to adjudicative decisions that duly consider
12 the victim’s safety, interest in avoiding unreasonable
13 delay, and just and timely claims to restitution from the
14 offender. These rights shall not be restricted except when
15 and to the degree dictated by a substantial interest in pub16 lic safety or the administration of criminal justice, or by
17 compelling necessity.
18

‘‘SECTION 3. Nothing in this article shall be con-

19 strued to provide grounds for a new trial or to authorize
20 any claim for damages. Only the victim or the victim’s
21 lawful representative may assert the rights established by
22 this article, and no person accused of the crime may obtain
23 any form of relief hereunder.
24

‘‘SECTION 4. Congress shall have power to enforce

25 by appropriate legislation the provisions of this article.
•HJ 48 IH

3
1 Nothing in this article shall affect the President’s author2 ity to grant reprieves or pardons.
3

‘‘SECTION 5. This article shall be inoperative unless

4 it has been ratified as an amendment to the Constitution
5 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
6 within 7 years from the date of its submission to the
7 States by the Congress. This article shall take effect on
8 the 180th day after the date of its ratification.’’.

Title:: 108 H. J. Res. 4 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States authorizing the Congress to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

108TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 4

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States authorizing
the Congress to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the
United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 7, 2003
Mr. CUNNINGHAM (for himself, Mr. MURTHA, Mr. KENNEDY of Minnesota,
Mr. MCINTYRE, Mr. WAMP, Mr. KING of New York, Mr. ROTHMAN, Mr.
FOLEY, Mrs. JOHNSON of Connecticut, Mr. ISSA, Mr. SHIMKUS, Mr.
STRICKLAND, Mr. KANJORSKI, Mrs. CUBIN, Mr. BRADY of Texas, Mr.
PETERSON of Minnesota, Mr. GREEN of Texas, Mrs. JO ANN DAVIS of
Virginia, Mr. SWEENEY, Mr. CRAMER, Mr. TOOMEY, Mrs. WILSON of
New Mexico, Mr. BILIRAKIS, Mr. SHERWOOD, Mr. BUYER, and Mr. NEY)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States authorizing the Congress to prohibit the physical
desecration of the flag of the United States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein),
4

SECTION 1. CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT.

5

The following article is proposed as an amendment

6 to the Constitution of the United States, which shall be
★

2
1 valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitu2 tion when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of
3 the several States within seven years after the date of its
4 submission for ratification:
5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘The Congress shall have power to prohibit the phys-

7 ical desecration of the flag of the United States.’’.

Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 21 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Gerald Brooks Hunt Solomon (R - NY)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States with respect to the proposal and the enactment of laws by popular vote of the people of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 21

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States with
respect to the proposal and the enactment of laws by popular vote
of the people of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. SOLOMON

JANUARY 7, 1997
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States with respect to the proposal and the enactment
of laws by popular vote of the people of the United
States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people of the United States shall

5 have the power to propose and enact laws in accordance
6 with this article, except with respect to carrying out the
7 powers granted to Congress in the 11th and 15th clauses
8 of article I, section 8, of this Constitution. This article
9 does not grant the people of the United States the power
10 to propose amendments to this Constitution.
11

‘‘SECTION 2. A law may be proposed by presenting

12 to the President a petition that sets forth the text of the
13 proposed law and contains signatures, collected within the
14 eighteen months prior to such presentation, of registered
15 voters equal in number to 3 percent of the ballots cast
16 in the last general election for President, and which in17 cludes the signatures of registered voters in each of one18 fourth of the States equal in number to 3 percent of the
19 ballots cast in the last general election for President in
20 each such State. Within ninety days after such presen21 tation, the President shall determine the validity of the
22 signatures contained in such petition through consultation
23 with the appropriate States. Upon a determination that
24 such petition contains the required number of valid signa25 tures, he shall certify such petition. He shall then direct

HJ 21 IH

3
1 that the proposed law be placed on the ballot at the next
2 general election held for choosing Members of the House
3 of Representatives occurring at least one hundred and
4 twenty days after such certification. The Congress shall
5 provide by law reasonable procedures for the preparation
6 and transmittal of such petitions, and for the certification
7 of signatures on such petitions. For the purposes of this
8 section, the term ‘State’ shall include the District of Co9 lumbia.
10

‘‘SECTION 3. A proposed law shall be enacted upon

11 receiving a majority of the number of electoral votes. For
12 purposes of this section, each State shall have a number
13 of electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and
14 Representatives to which such State is entitled in the Con15 gress. The District of Columbia shall have a number of
16 electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and Rep17 resentatives to which it would be entitled in the Congress
18 if it were a State, but in no event more than the number
19 of electoral votes of the least populous State. A proposed
20 law shall receive a proportion of the number of electoral
21 votes of each State equal to the proportion of the ballots
22 cast in such State with respect to such proposed law that
23 were cast for approval of such proposed law. In making
24 the computation, fractional numbers less than one-one25 thousandth shall be disregarded.

HJ 21 IH

4
1

‘‘SECTION 4. Any law enacted pursuant to this article

2 shall be a law the same as any other law of the United
3 States, except that any law to repeal or amend a law en4 acted pursuant to this article during the 2 years imme5 diately following its effective date must receive an affirma6 tive rollcall vote of two-thirds of the Members of each
7 House duly elected and sworn. No law, the enactment of
8 which is forbidden the Congress by this Constitution or
9 any amendment thereof, may be enacted by the people
10 under this article.
11

‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress and the people shall have

12 the power to enforce this article by appropriate legisla13 tion.’’.

Æ

HJ 21 IH

Title:: 106 H. J. Res. 45 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish the Federal income tax.
TEXT_Content:
IA

106TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 45

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish
the Federal income tax.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 14, 1999
Mr. SAM JOHNSON of Texas (for himself, Mr. THOMAS, Mr. PAUL, Mr.
LARGENT, Mr. COX, Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland, Mr. BARTON of Texas,
Mrs. MYRICK, Mr. HOSTETTLER, Mr. DOOLITTLE, Mr. TAUZIN, Mr.
CAMPBELL, Mr. TANCREDO, Mr. BALLENGER, Mr. GIBBONS, Mr.
HEFLEY, Mr. HAYWORTH, Mr. SCHAFFER, Mr. PITTS, Mr. COOKSEY,
Mrs. CHENOWETH, Mr. BARR of Georgia, Mr. BILIRAKIS, Mr. MILLER
of Florida, Mr. CAMP, Mr. SESSIONS, Mr. CHAMBLISS, Mr. HERGER, Mr.
LINDER, Mr. STUMP, Mr. EVERETT, Mr. DELAY, Mr. BONILLA, and Mr.
SKEEN) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to abolish the Federal income tax.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Three years after the ratification of this

6 article of amendment, the sixteenth article of amendment
7 to the Constitution of the United States is repealed, and
8 the Congress shall have no power to lay and collect taxes
9 on incomes, except in time of war declared by the Con10 gress.’’
11

‘‘SECTION 2. Not later than 180 days after the ratifi-

12 cation of the article of amendment proposed by this joint
13 resolution, the Secretary of the Treasury shall report to
14 the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Rep15 resentatives and the Committee on Finance of the Senate
16 recommendations for any legislation that may be nec17 essary to implement that article.’’.

Æ

Title:: 46 H.J. Res. 344 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States on the subjects of elections and free public schools.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States on
the subjects of elections and free public schools.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Bepresenta-

2 tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4 following amendment be proposed to the Constitution of the
5 United States:
6
7

AETIOLE
SECTION

—.

1. That all elections for President and Vice-

8

President of the United States, members of Congress, and

9

State and county officers shall be held on the first Tuesday

10 after the first Monday in November of the year in which the
11
12

election of the President of the United States shall occur.
That the several States of the United States, for the

13 purposes of elections, shall be, by the legislatures thereof,

14

divided into election precincts containing not to exceed five

15

hundred electors.

16

That each State shall enact and maintain a system of free

17

public schools, in organized school districts, for the attendance

18

of all children of school age, not less than one school district

19

in each election precinct, except in cities where union graded

20

public schools are maintained, in which schools there shall be

21

kept, during eight months of each year, free public schools-

22

for the attendance of all children between the ages of five and

23

twenty-one years, without distinction or separation on account

24

of race, color, or social condition.

25
26

That no public funds shall be appropriated by a State to
the support of sectarian schools.

27

That no citizen of the United States, born therein after

28

the adoption of this amendment, who has not attended

29

public or other schools for the period of five years, and who

30

is unable to read and write, shall be entitled to vote.

31

shall such citizens not voting be counted in the enumeration

32

for Eepresentatives.

Nor

33

That the failure of any State, within two years after the

34

adoption of this amendment, to carry out the provisions of

35

the same by appropriate legislation may be deemed a failure

36

to maintain a republican form of government, and the repre-

37

sentation in Congress and the counting of the electoral vote

38

of any such State may, by act of Congress, be denied such

39 State until such State shall have complied with the conditions
40 of such act of Congress.
41

That Congress shall have power to enforce this article hy

42 appropriate legislation.

Title:: 89 S.J. Res. 1 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating to succession to the Presidency and Vice-Presidency and to cases where the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office.
TEXT_Content:
89TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

d« J« KJUM*

IN THE HOUSE OE REPRESENTATIVES
22,1965
Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary
FEBRUARY

\

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
relating to succession to the Presidency and Vice Presidency
and to cases where the President is unable to discharge the
powers and duties of his office.
1

Besolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of

2 the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the following
4 article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitution of
5

the United States, which shall be valid to all intents and

6 purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by the
7 legislatures of three-fourths of the several States within seven
8 years from the date of its submission by the Congress:
I

1
2

"ARTICLE —
"SECTION

1. In case of the removal of the President

3 from office or of his death or resignation, the Vice President
4 shall become President.
5

"SEC.

2. Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of the

6 Vice President, the President shall nominate a Vice Presi1 dent who shall take office upon confirmation by a majority
8 vote of both Houses of Congress.
9

"SEC.

3. Whenever the President transmits to tjae' Presi-

10 dent of the Senate and the Speaker of the Bkrffse of Kepre11 sentatives his written declaration that" he is unable to dis12 charge the powers and duties of his office, such powers and
13 duties shall be discharged by the Vice President as Acting
14 President.
15

"SEC.

4. Whenever the Vice President, and a majority

16 of the principal officers of the executive departments or such
17 other body as Congress may by law provide, transmit to the
18 President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of
19 Representatives their written declaration that the President
20 is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, the
21 Vice President shall immediately assume the powers and
22 duties of the office as Acting President.
23

"SEC.

5. Whenever the President transmits to the Presi-

24 dent of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Eepre25 sentatives his written declaration that no inability exists, he

i

shall resume the powers and duties of his office unless the

2

Vice President, and a majority of the principal officers of

3

the executive departments or such other body as Congress

4 may by law provide, transmit within seven days to the
5 President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of
6 Eepresentatives their written declaration tliat the President
7 is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office.
8 Thereupon Congress shall immediately proceed to decide the
9 issue. If the Congress determines by two-thirds vote of both
10 Houses that the President is unable to discharge the powers
11 and duties of the office, the Vice President shall continue to
1^ discharge the same as Acting President; otherwise the Presi13 dent shall resume the powers and duties of his office."
Passed the Senate February 19, 1965.
Attest:

FELTON M. JOHNSTON,
Secretary.

LODGE
MAX,

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
providing for the election of President and Vice President.
1

liesolvcd by the Senate and House of Bepresentatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

3

That an amendment is hereby proposed to the Constitution

4 of the United States which shall he valid to all intents and
5 purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by threc6 fourths of the legislatures of the several States. Said
7

amendment shall be as follows:

8
9

"AETICLE
"SECTION

—

1. The executive power shall be vested in a

10 President of the United States of America. He shall hold
11 his office during the term of four years, and together with

55 AVAILABLE COPY

.i.

the Yice President, chosen for the same term, be elected

2 as provided in this Constitution.
3

"The electoral college system of electing the President

4 and Vice President of the United States is hereby abolished.
5 The President and Yice President shall be elected by the
6 people of the several States. The electors in each State
7

shall have the qualifications requisite for electors of the

8 most numerous branch of the State legislature. Congress
9 shall determine the time of such election, which shall be
10

the same throughout the United States.

Until otherwise

11

determined by the Congress, such election shall be held

12

on the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November

13

of the year preceding the year in which the regular term

14 of the President is to begin. Each State shall be entitled
15

to a number of electoral votes equal to the whole number

16

of Senators and Representatives to which such State may

17

be entitled in the Congress.

18

"Within forty-five days after such election, or at such

19

time as the Congress shall direct, the official custodian of

20

the election returns of each State shall make distinct lists

21

of all persons for whom votes were cast for President and

22 the number of votes for each, and the total vote of the
23

electors of the State for all persons for President, which

2^ lists he shall sign and certify and transmit sealed to the seat
2«> of the Government of the United States, directed to the

4 Bach person for whom votes were cast for President in each
5

State shall be credited with such proportion of the electoral

6

votes thereof as he received of the total vote of the electors

7

therein for President.

In making the computations, frac-

8 tional numbers less than one one-thousandth shall be disre9

garded unless a more detailed calculation would change the

10

result of the election. The person having the greatest lium-

-- ber of electoral votes for President shall be President. If
12

two or more persons shall have an equal and the highest

i.3

nuimjer 0f

guch votes, then the one for whom the greatest

■^ number of popular votes were cast shall be President.
15

The Vice President shall be likewise elected, at the

16

same time and in the same manner and subject to the same
provisions, as the President, but no person constitutionally

18

ineligible for the office of President shall be eligible to that
of Vice President of the United States.

20

"SEO.

2. Paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 of section 1, article

II, of the Constitution and the twelfth article of amendment
99

to the Constitution, are hereby repealed.

Title:: 50 H. Res. 21 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
1ST SESSION.

H. RES 21.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
JANUARY

4,1888.

Bead twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed.

Mr. LODGE introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
Whereas the first President of the United States was not inauffurated until the thirtieth day of April, in the year seventeen
hundred and eighty-nine; and
Whereas the day which was chosen by the Continental Congress
for the installation of the new Government then established
by the Constitution, the fourth day of March, does now cause
a public inconvenience in unduly curtailing and limiting the
second session of every Congress; and
Whereas it is fitting that the one hundredth anniversary of the
inauguration of George Washington as the first President of
the United States be commemorated by the inauguration of
his successor in eighteen hundred and eighty-nine upon the
same day, and that this should be the day hereafter for the
beginning of successive administrations of the Government:
Therefore,
1

Besolved by the Senate and House of Bepresentatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol-

4

lowing article be proposed to the legislatures of the several

5

States as an amendment to the Constitution of the United

6

States, as part of the Constitution, namely:

7

AETIOLE

XVI.

8

The term of office of the President and of the Fiftieth

9

Congress shall continue until the last Tuesday of April in the

10

year eighteen hundred and eighty-nine, at noon.

The Sena™

11

tors whose existing term would otherwise expire on the fourth

12

day of March in the year eighteen hundred and eighty-nine,

13

or thereafter, shall continue in office until noon of the last

14

Tuesday in April succeeding such expiration ; and the last

15

Tuesday in April, at noon, shall thereafter be substituted for

16

the fourth of March as the commencement and termination of

17

the official term of the President, Vice-President, Senators,

18

and Representatives in Congress.

19

fourth of March, occur in the twelfth amendment to the Con-

20

stitution, the words, the last Tuesday in April, are hereby

21

substituted.

Title:: 106 H. J. Res. 29 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide a procedure by which the States may propose constitutional amendments.
TEXT_Content:
IA

106TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 29

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
a procedure by which the States may propose constitutional amendments.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FEBRUARY 11, 1999
Mr. BLILEY (for himself, Mr. KOLBE, Mr. GOODE, Mr. STUMP, Mr. GILLMOR,
Mr. METCALF, Mr. SHADEGG, and Mr. MANZULLO) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide a procedure by which the States may
propose constitutional amendments.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing is proposed as an amendment to the Constitution
5 of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with8 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica9 tion:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Two-thirds of the legislatures of the sev-

3 eral States may propose an amendment to the Constitu4 tion by enacting identical legislation in each such legisla5 ture proposing the amendment. If two-thirds of the legisla6 tures of the several States enact such legislation, the legis7 lature first proposing the amendment shall submit the pro8 posed amendment to the Congress.
9

‘‘SECTION 2. If a proposed amendment is submitted

10 to the Congress under this article and, before the date of
11 the second adjournment of Congress sine die occurring
12 after the proposed amendment is so submitted, two-thirds
13 of each House vote against legislation expressly disapprov14 ing the proposed amendment, the proposed amendment
15 shall be deemed to be submitted to the several States for
16 their consideration.
17

‘‘SECTION 3. If, as of the date of the second adjourn-

18 ment of Congress sine die occurring after a proposed
19 amendment is submitted to Congress under this article,
20 the proposed amendment has not been submitted to the
21 several States for their consideration under section 2, and
22 two-thirds of each House have not voted for legislation ex23 pressly disapproving the proposed amendment, the pro24 posed amendment shall be deemed to be submitted to the
25 several States for their consideration.
•HJ 29 IH

3
1

‘‘SECTION 4. A proposed amendment submitted to

2 the several States for their consideration under this article
3 shall be valid as part of the Constitution when ratified
4 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States.
5

‘‘SECTION 5. This article shall not be construed as

6 limiting the power of the States or the Congress under
7 Article V of this Constitution.
8

‘‘SECTION 6. The Congress shall have power to en-

9 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Æ

Title:: 107 H. J. Res. 91 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect the rights of crime victims.
TEXT_Content:
IA

107TH CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 91

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect
the rights of crime victims.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MAY 2, 2002
Mr. CHABOT (for himself, Mr. BARCIA, Mr. KELLER, Mr. FLAKE, Mr. GREEN
of Wisconsin, Mr. BRADY of Texas, Mr. SAXTON, Mr. SOUDER, Mr. WALDEN, Mr. FOSSELLA, Mr. MCNULTY, Mr. SHAYS, Mr. ROYCE, Mr. KENNEDY of Minnesota, Mr. ENGLISH, Mr. GALLEGLY, and Ms. PRYCE of
Ohio) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to protect the rights of crime victims.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States, and which shall take effect on the 180th day after
2 ratification of this article:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The rights of victims of violent crime,

5 being capable of protection without denying the constitu6 tional rights of those accused of victimizing them, are
7 hereby established and shall not be denied by any State
8 or the United States and may be restricted only as pro9 vided in this article.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. A victim of violent crime shall have the

11 right to reasonable and timely notice of any public pro12 ceeding involving the crime and of any release or escape
13 of the accused; the rights not to be excluded from such
14 public proceeding and reasonably to be heard at public re15 lease, plea, sentencing, reprieve, and pardon proceedings;
16 and the right to adjudicative decisions that duly consider
17 the victim’s safety, interest in avoiding unreasonable
18 delay, and just and timely claims to restitution from the
19 offender. These rights shall not be restricted except when
20 and to the degree dictated by a substantial interest in pub21 lic safety or the administration of criminal justice, or by
22 compelling necessity.
23

‘‘SECTION 3. Nothing in this article shall be con-

24 strued to provide grounds for a new trial or to authorize
25 any claim for damages. Only the victim or the victim’s
•HJRES 91 IH

3
1 lawful representative may assert the rights established by
2 this article, and no person accused of the crime may obtain
3 any form of relief hereunder.
4

‘‘SECTION 4. Congress shall have power to enforce

5 by appropriate legislation the provisions of this article.
6 Nothing in this article shall affect the President’s author7 ity to grant reprieves or pardons.
8

‘‘SECTION 5. This article shall be inoperative unless

9 it shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Con10 stitution by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
11 States within seven years from the date of its submission
12 to the States by the Congress.’’.

Æ

•HJRES 91 IH

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 210 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Gerald Brooks Hunt Solomon (R - NY)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States with respect to the proposal and the enactment of laws by popular vote of the people of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 210

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States with
respect to the proposal and the enactment of laws by popular vote
of the people of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. SOLOMON

JUNE 8, 1993
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States with respect to the proposal and the enactment
of laws by popular vote of the people of the United
States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people of the United States shall

6 have the power to propose and enact laws in accordance
7 with this article, except with respect to carrying out the
8 powers granted to Congress in the 11th and 15th clauses
9 of article I, section 8, of this Constitution. This article
10 does not grant the people of the United States the power
11 to propose amendments to this Constitution.
12

‘‘SECTION 2. A law may be proposed by presenting

13 to the President a petition that sets forth the text of the
14 proposed law and contains signatures, collected within the
15 eighteen months prior to such presentation, of registered
16 voters equal in number to 3 percent of the ballots cast
17 in the last general election for President, and which in18 cludes the signatures of registered voters in each of one19 fourth of the States equal in number to 3 percent of the
20 ballots cast in the last general election for President in
21 each such State. Within ninety days after such presen22 tation, the President shall determine the validity of the
23 signatures contained in such petition through consultation
24 with the appropriate States. Upon a determination that
25 such petition contains the required number of valid signa•HJ 210 IH

3
1 tures, he shall certify such petition. He shall then direct
2 that the proposed law be placed on the ballot at the next
3 general election held for choosing Members of the House
4 of Representatives occurring at least one hundred and
5 twenty days after such certification. The Congress shall
6 provide by law reasonable procedures for the preparation
7 and transmittal of such petitions, and for the certification
8 of signatures on such petitions. For the purposes of this
9 section, the term ‘State’ shall include the District of Co10 lumbia.
11

‘‘SECTION 3. A proposed law shall be enacted upon

12 receiving a majority of the number of electoral votes. For
13 purposes of this section, each State shall have a number
14 of electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and
15 Representatives to which such State is entitled in the Con16 gress. The District of Columbia shall have a number of
17 electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and Rep18 resentatives to which it would be entitled in the Congress
19 if it were a State, but in no event more than the number
20 of electoral votes of the least populous State. A proposed
21 law shall receive a proportion of the number of electoral
22 votes of each State equal to the proportion of the ballots
23 cast in such State with respect to such proposed law that
24 were cast for approval of such proposed law. In making

•HJ 210 IH

4
1 the computation, fractional numbers less than one-one2 thousandth shall be disregarded.
3

‘‘SECTION 4. Any law enacted pursuant to this article

4 shall be a law the same as any other law of the United
5 States, except that any law to repeal or amend a law en6 acted pursuant to this article during the 2 years imme7 diately following its effective date must receive an affirma8 tive rollcall vote of two-thirds of the Members of each
9 House duly elected and sworn. No law, the enactment of
10 which is forbidden the Congress by this Constitution or
11 any amendment thereof, may be enacted by the people
12 under this article.

of those candidates in favor of or those against the ratified-

18

19

to vote against the ratification, then those candidates w»°

such delegates or their alternates shall meet in convention

—

eral papers, but each paper shall contain the full text of

posed amendment to the Governors of all of the States with

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 176 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish the Federal income tax.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 176

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish
the Federal income tax.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 24, 1996
Mr. SAM JOHNSON of Texas (for himself, Mr. HASTERT, Mr. FIELDS of
Texas, Mr. TAUZIN, Mr. CHRYSLER, Ms. DUNN of Washington, Mr.
CRANE, Mr. CHRISTENSEN, Mr. HANCOCK, Mr. CUNNINGHAM, Mr.
BUNNING of Kentucky, Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland, Mr. SKEEN, Mr.
HANSEN, Mrs. CHENOWETH, Mr. LAUGHLIN, Mr. ROHRABACHER, Mr.
HAYWORTH, Mr. HUNTER, Mr. YOUNG of Alaska, Mrs. SEASTRAND, Mr.
ENSIGN, Mr. FRISA, Mr. BONILLA, Mr. STOCKMAN, Mr. GRAHAM, Mr.
BURR, Mr. GOSS, Mr. TRAFICANT, Mr. COLLINS of Georgia, Mr. THOMAS, Mr. LARGENT, Mr. DORNAN, Mr. BONO, Mr. DREIER, Mrs. CUBIN,
Mr. HALL of Texas, Mr. DICKEY, Mr. DOOLITTLE, Mr. KNOLLENBERG,
Mr. HOSTETTLER, and Mr. NORWOOD) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to abolish the Federal income tax.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents

2
1 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
2 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with3 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica4 tion:
5
6

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Three years after the ratification of this

7 article of amendment, the sixteenth article of amendment
8 to the Constitution of the United States is repealed, and
9 the Congress shall have no power to lay and collect taxes
10 on incomes, except in time of war declared by the Con11 gress.’’
12

‘‘SECTION 2. Not later than 180 days after the ratifi-

13 cation of the article of amendment proposed by this joint
14 resolution, the Secretary of the Treasury shall report to
15 the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Rep16 resentatives and the Committee on Finance of the Senate
17 recommendations for any legislation that may be nec18 essary to implement that article.’’.

IIA

108TH CONGRESS
2D SESSION

S. J. RES. 30

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating
to marriage.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
MARCH 22, 2004
Mr. ALLARD (for himself, Mr. BROWNBACK, Mr. ENZI, Mr. INHOFE, Mr. MILLER, Mr. LOTT, Mr. SANTORUM, Mr. SESSIONS, and Mr. SHELBY) introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relating to marriage.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States:

2
1
2
3

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.

‘‘This Article may be cited as the ‘Federal Marriage

4 Amendment’.
5
6

‘‘SECTION 2. MARRIAGE AMENDMENT.

‘‘Marriage in the United States shall consist only of

7 the union of a man and a woman. Neither this Constitu8 tion, nor the constitution of any State, shall be construed
9 to require that marriage or the legal incidents thereof be
10 conferred upon any union other than the union of a man
11 and a woman.’’.
