Title:: 105 H. J. Res. 93 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Virgil H. Goode Jr. (D - VA)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating to the power of the several States to propose amendments to the Constitution.
TEXT_Content:
IA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 93

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating
to the power of the several States to propose amendments to the Constitution.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. GOODE

JULY 31, 1997
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relating to the power of the several States to
propose amendments to the Constitution.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with8 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica9 tion:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘In addition to other methods established in this

3 Constitution for proposing amendments to this Constitu4 tion, whenever the legislatures of three-fourths of the sev5 eral States shall propose and adopt an identical amend6 ment to this Constitution, related to but one subject, that
7 amendment shall be valid as a part of this Constitution,
8 without any action being required by the Congress, upon
9 receipt by the Clerk of the Supreme Court of certified cop10 ies of that amendment from States which represent three11 fourths of the several States; provided that the Clerk re12 ceives such certified copies within a seven-year period be13 ginning on the date the Clerk receives the first certified
14 copy of the proposed amendment; that each State shall
15 retain the power to rescind its action to propose and adopt
16 the amendment until the expiration of the seven-year pe17 riod or the date of receipt by the Clerk of certified copies
18 of the same amendment from three-fourths of the several
19 States, whichever first occurs; and that no State, without
20 its consent, shall be deprived of its equal suffrage in the
21 Senate.
22

‘‘Upon receipt from the first ten States of the iden-

23 tical proposed amendment, the Supreme Court shall with24 in sixty days thereafter rule whether the amendment is,
25 in fact, related to one subject only. If the Supreme Court

HJ 93 IH

3
1 rules that the amendment is related to but one subject,
2 or if the Supreme Court fails to rule on the issue within
3 the sixty days, the amendment shall be conclusively pre4 sumed to meet the one-subject standard. If the Supreme
5 Court rules that the amendment fails to meet the one-sub6 ject standard, the proposed amendment shall be invalid.’’.

Æ

Title:: 117 H. J. Res. 14 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish the electoral college and to provide for the direct election of the President and Vice President of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
IA

117TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 14

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to abolish
the electoral college and to provide for the direct election of the President
and Vice President of the United States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 11, 2021
Mr. COHEN (for himself, Ms. LOFGREN, Ms. ESHOO, Ms. SCHAKOWSKY, Ms.
BROWNLEY, Mr. DEFAZIO, Mr. ESPAILLAT, Mr. GARAMENDI, and Mr.
COOPER) submitted the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to abolish the electoral college and to provide
for the direct election of the President and Vice President of the United States.

pamtmann on DSKBC07HB2PROD with BILLS

Whereas the Founders of the Nation established the electoral
college in an era of limited nationwide communication
and information sharing;
Whereas the electoral college is premised on an antiquated
theory that citizens will have a better chance of knowing
about electors from their home States than about Presidential candidates from out of State;
Whereas the development of mass media and the internet has
made information about Presidential candidates easily ac-

VerDate Sep 11 2014

23:30 Jan 11, 2021

Jkt 019200

PO 00000

Frm 00001

Fmt 6652

Sfmt 6300

E:\BILLS\HJ14.IH

HJ14

2
cessible to United States citizens across the country and
around the world;
Whereas citizens now have a far better chance of knowing
about out-of-State Presidential candidates than about
Presidential electors from their home State;
Whereas Thomas Jefferson wrote, ‘‘I am not an advocate for
frequent changes in laws and constitutions, but laws and
institutions must go hand in hand with the progress of
the human mind. As that becomes more developed, more
enlightened, as new discoveries are made, new truths discovered and manners and opinions change, with the
change of circumstances, institutions must advance also
to keep pace with the times. We might as well require a
man to wear still the coat which fitted him when a boy
as civilized society to remain ever under the regimen of
their barbarous ancestors.’’;
Whereas since the Nation’s founding, United States citizens
have amended the Constitution to expand the opportunity
for citizens to directly elect their elected leaders;
Whereas the 15th Amendment guarantees the right of all citizens to vote regardless of race;
Whereas the 19th Amendment guarantees the right of all citizens to vote regardless of gender;

pamtmann on DSKBC07HB2PROD with BILLS

Whereas the 26th Amendment guarantees the right of all citizens 18 years of age and older to vote regardless of age;
Whereas the 17th Amendment establishes both a precedent
and a preference for the direct election of citizens’ elected
representatives; and
Whereas the electoral college has become an anachronism:
Now, therefore, be it

6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The people of the United States shall

6 have the power to propose and enact laws in accordance
7 with this article, except with respect to carrying out the
8 powers granted to Congress in the 11th and 15th clauses
9 of article I, section 8, of this Constitution. This article
10 does not grant the people of the United States the power
11 to propose amendments to this Constitution.
12

‘‘SECTION 2. A law may be proposed by presenting

13 to the President a petition that sets forth the text of the
14 proposed law and contains signatures, collected within the
15 eighteen months prior to such presentation, of registered
16 voters equal in number to 3 percent of the ballots cast
17 in the last general election for President, and which in18 cludes the signatures of registered voters in each of one19 fourth of the States equal in number to 3 percent of the
20 ballots cast in the last general election for President in
21 each such State. Within ninety days after such presen22 tation, the President shall determine the validity of the
23 signatures contained in such petition through consultation
24 with the appropriate States. Upon a determination that
25 such petition contains the required number of valid signa•HJ 11 IH

3
1 tures, he shall certify such petition. He shall then direct
2 that the proposed law be placed on the ballot at the next
3 general election held for choosing Members of the House
4 of Representatives occurring at least one hundred and
5 twenty days after such certification. The Congress shall
6 provide by law reasonable procedures for the preparation
7 and transmittal of such petitions, and for the certification
8 of signatures on such petitions. For the purposes of this
9 section, the term ‘State’ shall include the District of Co10 lumbia.
11

‘‘SECTION 3. A proposed law shall be enacted upon

12 receiving a majority of the number of electoral votes. For
13 purposes of this section, each State shall have a number
14 of electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and
15 Representatives to which such State is entitled in the Con16 gress. The District of Columbia shall have a number of
17 electoral votes equal to the number of Senators and Rep18 resentatives to which it would be entitled in the Congress
19 if it were a State, but in no event more than the number
20 of electoral votes of the least populous State. A proposed
21 law shall receive a proportion of the number of electoral
22 votes of each State equal to the proportion of the ballots
23 cast in such State with respect to such proposed law that
24 were cast for approval of such proposed law. In making

•HJ 11 IH

4
1 the computation, fractional numbers less than one-one2 thousandth shall be disregarded.
3

‘‘SECTION 4. Any law enacted pursuant to this article

4 shall be a law the same as any other law of the United
5 States, except that any law to repeal or amend a law en6 acted pursuant to this article during the 2 years imme7 diately following its effective date must receive an affirma8 tive rollcall vote of two-thirds of the Members of each
9 House duly elected and sworn. No law, the enactment of
10 which is forbidden the Congress by this Constitution or
11 any amendment thereof, may be enacted by the people
12 under this article.
13

‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress and the people shall have

14 the power to enforce this article by appropriate legisla15 tion.’’.

Title:: 101 H. J. Res. 50 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: JOINT RESOLUTION Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States allowing an item veto in appropriations bills.
TEXT_Content:
IA

101ST CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 50

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States allowing an
item veto in appropriations bills.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
3, 1989
Mr. EMERSON introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary
JANUARY

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States allowing an item veto in appropriations bills.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion, which shall be valid to all intents and purposes as part
6 of the Constitution when ratified by the legislatures of three7 fourths of the several States:
8
9

"ARTICLE
"SECTION

—

1. The President shall have the power to

10 disapprove any appropriation or provision and approve any

2
1 other appropriation or provision in the same appropriation
2 bill. In such case he shall, in signing the bill, designate the
3 appropriations and provisions disapproved; and shall return a
4 copy of such appropriations and provisions, with his objec5 tions, to the House in which the bill shall have originated;
6 and the same proceedings shall then be had as in case of
7 other bills disapproved by the President.
8

"SECTION

2. This article shall be inoperative unless it

9 shall have been ratified as an amendment to the Constitution
10 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
11 within seven years from the date of its submission.".

Title:: 46 H.J. Res. 172 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States in relation to the election of President and Vico-President, providing for their election by a majority of the votes of the people and the abolition of the electoral college.
TEXT_Content:
[Printer's No., 1718.
46TH COMRESS,
2D SESSION.

II. RES. 172.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
JANUARY

19, 1880.

Bead twice, referred to the Select Committee on the State of the Law respecting Ascertainment and Declaration of Result of Election of President and
Yice-President, and ordered to be printed.

Mr. RICHARD W. TOWNSHEND, by unanimous consent, introduced
the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
in relation to the election of President and Vice-President,
providing for their election by a majority of the votes of the
people, and the abolition of the Electoral College.
1

Resolved by the Senate. and House of Representa-

2

tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4 following amendment to the Constitution of the United
5

States be proposed to the legislatures of the several States,

6 which, when ratified by three-fourths of said legislatures, shall
7 become and be a part of the Constitution, namely:
8
9
10
11

ARTICLE

XVI.

The second and third divisions of article second shall be
struck out.
All that part of the twelfth amendment of the Constitu-

12

tion from the beginning down to and including the words

13

"if soch number be a majority of the whole number of elect-

14

ors appointed" to be struck out and the following substituted:

15

Hereafter the President and Vice-President of the United

16

States shall be chosen by the people of the respective States

17

in the following manner:

18

The citizens of each State who shall be qualified to vote

19

for members of Congress, shall, on the first Tuesday after the

20

first Monday in November in the year eighteen hundred and

21

eighty, and on the same day in every four years thereafter,

22

cast their votes by ballot for candidates for President and

23

Vice-President, one of whom, at least, shall not be an

24

inhabitant of the State with himself; and proper returns of

25

the votes so cast shall be made under seal, within ten days,

26

to the chief justice or to- the presiding judge of the highest

27 judicial tribunal in the State.
28

The right of fixing the places in the State where the

29

election shall be held, the manner of holding the same, and

30

of canvassing the votes and certifying the returns to the said

31

chief justice or presiding judge is reserved exclusively to

32

the legislatures of the States.

33

The highest judicial tribunal of each State shall meet

34

and be in session on the third Tuesday next following said

35

election, and the presiding judge of said tribunal shall pub-

36

licly open said returns in the presence of the members of the

37

said tribunal, and the votes shall then be counted by the said

38

tribunal.

39

nal to cause three certificates of the numbers of votes so cast

It shall be the duty of the members of said tribu-

40 in said State for President and Vice-President, to be made and
41

certified by a majority of the members of said tribunal and

42

attested by the seal of said tribunal.

43

The certificates of the members of said tribunal shall be

44 disposed of by them in the following manner:
45

First. They shall, by writing, under the hands of a ma-

46 jority of them, appoint a person to take charge of and deliver
47

to the President of the Senate, at the seat of government, be-

48 fore the second Monday in January next after their meeting,
49

one of the certificates.

50

Second. They shall forthwith forward, by the post-office,

51

to the President of the Senate, at the seat of government, one

52

other of the certificates.

53

Third. They shall forthwith cause the other of the cer-

54 tificates to be delivered to the judge of that district in which
55

the tribunal shall assemble.

56

Whenever a certificate of votes from any State shall not

57

be received by the President of the Senate on or before the

58

day indicated in the preceding section, he shall forthwith

59

notify the said presiding judge, who shall send a special mes-

60 senger to the district judge, in whose custody one certificate

61

of the votes from that State has been lodged, and such judge

62

shall forthwith transmit that certificate to the seat of govern-

63

ment.

64
65

Congress shall be in session on the second Monday in
December succeeding every meeting of the electors.

66

The Senate and House of Representatives shall meet in

67

the Hall of the House of Representatives at one o'clock, post

68

meridiem, on that day; the President of the Senate shall

69

be their presiding officer.

70

Two tellers shall be previously appointed on the part of

71

the Senate, and two on the part of the House of Representa-

72

tives.

73

The President of the Senate shall then open all the cer-

74

tificates, and papers purporting to be certificates, of the elec-

75

toral votes; the votes shall then be counted by the two

76

Houses of Congress in the alphabetical order of the States.

77

The person having the greatest number of votes cast in

78

all the States for President, shall be President, if such num-

79

ber be equal to a majority of the whole vote given; but,

80

if no person have such a majority, then a second election

81

shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in

82

the month of January then next ensuing, between the per-

83

sons having the two highest numbers for the office of Presi-

84 dent, which second election shall be conducted, the result
85 certified, and the votes counted in the same manner as in
86 the first; and the person having the greatest number of
87 votes for President, shall fee President.

But if two or more

88 persons shall have received the greatest and equal number
89 of votes at the second election, the House of Representatives
90 shall choose one of them for President, as is now prescribed
91 by the Constitution.
92

The person having the greatest number of votes for Vice-

93 President at the first election, shall be the Vice-President, if
94 such number be equal to a majority of the whole number of
95 votes given, and if no person have such majority then a second
96 election shall take place between the persons having the two
97 highest numbers on the same day that the second election is
98 held for President, and the person having the highest number
99 of votes for Vice-President, shall be the Vice-President.

But

100 if two or more persons shall have received the greatest num101 ber of votes in the second election, then the Senate shall
102 choose one of them for Vice-President, as is now provided in
103 the Constitution.

But when a second election shall be neces-

104 sary in the case of Vice-President, and not necessary in the
105 case of President, then the Senate shall choose a Vice-Presi106 dent from the persons having the two highest numbers in the
107 first election, as is prescribed in the Constitution.

6
108

Strike out from the twelfth amendment the words

109 "from the persons having the highest numbers, not exceeding
110 three, on the list of those voted for as President".
111

Strike out the words "electors appointed" where they

112 occur in the twelfth amendment and insert the words "votes
113 cast at the election".

IIA

107TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 1

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating
to voluntary school prayer.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
JANUARY 22, 2001
Mr. THURMOND introduced the following joint resolution; which was read
twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relating to voluntary school prayer.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years after the date of its submission
9 by the Congress:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to

3 prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or
4 other public institutions. No person shall be required by
5 the United States or by any State to participate in prayer.
6 Neither the United States nor any State shall compose
7 the words of any prayer to be said in public schools.’’.

JONES

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing* an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
Whereas it is obviously evident that applied representative government would be conducive to a more stable tranquility
and inure to the general welfare: Therefore be it
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That in lieu

4

of the third paragraph of section two, article one, of the

5

Constitution of the United States, and in lieu of section two,

6

Article XIV of amendments to the Constitution of the

7

United States, the following be submitted, which shall be

8

valid to all intents and purposes as a part of the Constitu-

9

tion when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the

10

States of the Union:

11

''Representatives shall be apportioned among the

12

several States according to their respective number of elec-

13

tors vocationally.

But when the right to vote-at any elec-

1

tion for choice of electors for President and Vice President

2

of the United States, Representatives in Congress, the execu-

3

tive and judicial officers of a State, or the members of the

4

legislature thereof, is denied to any elector of such State

5

and citizen of the United States, or in any way abridged,

6

except for participation in rebellion or other crime, the basis

7

for representation therein shall be apportioned according to

8

the highest number of votes cast in each of the several States

9

for President after each presidential election.

10

"2. This amendment shall not be construed as affecting

11

the election or terms of any Representative chosen before

12

it becomes valid as a part of the Constitution.

13

"3. That Congress shall have power to enforce, by

14

appropriate legislation, the provisions of this amendment."

Title:: 104 S. J. Res. 1 (Introduced in the Senate)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to require a balanced budget.
TEXT_Content:
II

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 1

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to require
a balanced budget.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
JANUARY 4, 1995
Mr. DOLE (for himself, Mr. HATCH, Mr. SIMON, Mr. THURMOND, Mr. HEFLIN, Mr. CRAIG, Ms. MOSELEY-BRAUN, Mr. BROWN, Mr. KOHL, Mr.
SIMPSON, Mr. GRASSLEY, Mr. SPECTER, Mr. KYL, Mrs. FEINSTEIN, Mr.
NICKLES, Mr. MURKOWSKI, Mr. BRYAN, Mrs. HUTCHISON, Mr. EXON,
Mr. SHELBY, Mr. CAMPBELL, Mr. SMITH, Mr. COHEN, Mr. PRESSLER,
Mr. GREGG, Mr. GORTON, Mr. ASHCROFT, Mr. BURNS, Mr. MCCONNELL, Mr. INHOFE, Mr. GRAMM, Mr. LOTT, Mr. DEWINE, Ms. SNOWE,
Mr. ROTH, Mr. LUGAR, Mr. BOND, Mr. THOMAS, Mr. COVERDELL, Mr.
SANTORUM, Mr. GRAMS, and Mr. MACK) introduced the following joint
resolution; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the
Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to require a balanced budget.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution, which shall be valid to all intents and purposes
6 as part of the Constitution when ratified by the legisla-

2
1 tures of three-fourths of the several States within seven
2 years after the date of its submission to the States for
3 ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Total outlays for any fiscal year shall

6 not exceed total receipts for that fiscal year, unless three7 fifths of the whole number of each House of Congress shall
8 provide by law for a specific excess of outlays over receipts
9 by a rollcall vote.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. The limit on the debt of the United

11 States held by the public shall not be increased, unless
12 three-fifths of the whole number of each House shall pro13 vide by law for such an increase by a rollcall vote.
14

‘‘SECTION 3. Prior to each fiscal year, the President

15 shall transmit to the Congress a proposed budget for the
16 United States Government for that fiscal year, in which
17 total outlays do not exceed total receipts.
18

‘‘SECTION 4. No bill to increase revenue shall become

19 law unless approved by a majority of the whole number
20 of each House by a rollcall vote.
21

‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress may waive the provisions

22 of this article for any fiscal year in which a declaration
23 of war is in effect. The provisions of this article may be
24 waived for any fiscal year in which the United States is
25 engaged in military conflict which causes an imminent and
•SJ 1 IS

3
1 serious military threat to national security and is so de2 clared by a joint resolution, adopted by a majority of the
3 whole number of each House, which becomes law.
4

‘‘SECTION 6. The Congress shall enforce and imple-

5 ment this article by appropriate legislation, which may rely
6 on estimates of outlays and receipts.
7

‘‘SECTION 7. Total receipts shall include all receipts

8 of the United States Government except those derived
9 from borrowing. Total outlays shall include all outlays of
10 the United States Government except for those for repay11 ment of debt principal.
12

‘‘SECTION 8. This article shall take effect beginning

13 with fiscal year 2002 or with the second fiscal year begin14 ning after its ratification, whichever is later.’’.

Æ

•SJ 1 IS

Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 37 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide for four-year terms for Representatives and to limit the number of terms Senators and Representatives may serve.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 37

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to provide
for four-year terms for Representatives and to limit the number of
terms Senators and Representatives may serve.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 5, 1993
Mr. MCCOLLUM (for himself, Mr. ROHRABACHER, Mr. RAVENEL, Mr. MCMILLAN, Mr. GOSS, Mr. PACKARD, Mr. HOEKSTRA, Mr. BEREUTER, Mr.
CALVERT, Mr. KYL, Mr. POMBO, Mr. STEARNS, Mr. ALLARD, Mr.
LIGHTFOOT, Mr. SANTORUM, Mr. BARRETT of Nebraska, Mr. BUYER,
Mr. CRAPO, Mr. GOODLATTE, Mr. HOKE, Mr. TALENT, and Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland) introduced the following joint resolution; which was
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to provide for four-year terms for Representatives
and to limit the number of terms Senators and Representatives may serve.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years from the date of its submission
3 by the Congress:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The term of office of a Representative

6 in Congress shall be four years, except for two-year terms
7 as provided in this section. Immediately after the Rep8 resentatives in Congress shall be assembled for the first
9 term with respect to which this section applies, they shall
10 be divided by lot as equally as may be into two classes.
11 The terms of the Representatives of the first class shall
12 expire at the end of the second year, and of the second
13 class at the end of the fourth year, so that one-half may
14 be chosen every second year. In order to meet the require15 ments of reapportionment, all offices of Representatives
16 in Congress shall be open for election in years ending in
17 two and the same process of division into two classes de18 scribed hereinbefore shall recur upon the first assembly
19 of Members after each such election. The House of Rep20 resentatives shall adopt procedures to insure that the size
21 of the two classes of seats shall remain as equal as possible
22 despite changes occurring in the total number of seats in
23 the House of Representatives or in the apportionment of
24 Members among the several States.

HJ 37 IH

3
1

‘‘SECTION 2. No person who has been elected to the

2 Senate two times shall be eligible for election or appoint3 ment to the Senate. No person who has been elected to
4 the House of Representatives a total of four times, or has
5 been elected three times to four-year terms, shall be eligi6 ble for election to the House of Representatives.
7

‘‘SECTION 3. For purposes of determining eligibility

8 for election under section 2, only elections occurring by
9 reason of the expiration of the term of office of a Member
10 and elections to terms of office beginning more than one
11 year after the date of the ratification of this article shall
12 be taken into account.
13

‘‘SECTION 4. The first clause of section 2 of article

14 I of the Constitution of the United States is hereby re15 pealed.
16

‘‘SECTION 5. Section 1 shall apply with respect to

17 terms of office beginning more than one year after the
18 date of the ratification of this article. Section 2 shall take
19 effect when the first terms of office begin with respect to
20 which section 1 applies.’’.
Æ

HJ 37 IH

Title:: 104 S. J. Res. 6 (Introduced in the Senate)

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

to voluntary school prayer.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

Mr. THURMOND (for himself, Mr. FAIRCLOTH, Mr. LOTT, and Mr. SHELBY)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relating to voluntary school prayer.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is hereby proposed as an amendment to the
5 Constitution of the United States, which shall be valid to
6 all intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if rati7 fied by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years from the date of its submission
9 to the States by the Congress:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to

3 prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or
4 other public institutions. No person shall be required by
5 the United States or by any State to participate in prayer.
6 Neither the United States nor any State shall compose
7 the words of any prayer to be said in public schools.’’.

the Federal income tax.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
APRIL 10, 1997
Mr. SAM JOHNSON of Texas (for himself, Mr. NORWOOD, Mr. HOSTETTLER,
Mr. HALL of Texas, Mr. HAYWORTH, Mr. LARGENT, Mr. YOUNG of Alaska, Mr. THOMAS, Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland, Mr. TAUZIN, Mrs.

HERGER, Mr. BURTON of Indiana, Mr. SPENCE, and Mr. ENSIGN) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee
on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to abolish the Federal income tax.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Three years after the ratification of this

5 article of amendment, the sixteenth article of amendment
6 to the Constitution of the United States is repealed, and
7 the Congress shall have no power to lay and collect taxes
8 on incomes, except in time of war declared by the Con9 gress.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. Not later than 180 days after the ratifi-

11 cation of the article of amendment proposed by this joint
12 resolution, the Secretary of the Treasury shall report to
13 the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Rep14 resentatives and the Committee on Finance of the Senate
15 recommendations for any legislation that may be nec16 essary to implement that article.’’.

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 56 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to restrict the requirement of citizenship at birth by virtue of birth in the United States to persons with a legal resident mother or father.
TEXT_Content:
IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 56

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to restrict
the requirement of citizenship at birth by virtue of birth in the United
States to persons with a legal resident mother or father.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. BEILENSON

JANUARY 19, 1995
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to restrict the requirement of citizenship at birth
by virtue of birth in the United States to persons with
a legal resident mother or father.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. All persons born in the United States,

5 and subject to the jurisdiction thereof, of a mother or fa6 ther who is a legal resident of the United States and all
7 persons naturalized in the United States are citizens of
8 the United States and of the State wherein they reside.
9 The first sentence of section 1 of the fourteenth article
10 of amendment to the Constitution of the United States
11 is hereby repealed.
12

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have power to en-

13 force before this article by appropriate legislation.
14

‘‘SECTION 3. This article shall apply to persons born

15 after the date of its ratification.’’.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States with respect to tax limitations.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years after the date of its submission
9 for ratification:
10
11

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Any bill, resolution, or other legislative

12 measure changing the internal revenue laws shall require
13 for final adoption in each House the concurrence of two14 thirds of the Members of that House voting and present,
•HJ 94 IH

3
1 unless that bill, resolution, or other legislative measure is
2 determined at the time of adoption, in a reasonable man3 ner prescribed by law, not to increase the internal revenue
4 by more than a de minimis amount. For the purposes of
5 determining any increase in the internal revenue under
6 this section, there shall be excluded any increase resulting
7 from the lowering of an effective rate of any tax. On any
8 vote for which the concurrence of two-thirds is required
9 under this article, the yeas and nays of the Members of
10 either House shall be entered on the Journal of that
11 House.
12

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress may waive the require-

13 ments of this article when a declaration of war is in effect.
14 The Congress may also waive this article when the United
15 States is engaged in military conflict which causes an im16 minent and serious threat to national security and is so
17 declared by a joint resolution, adopted by a majority of
18 the whole number of each House, which becomes law. Any
19 increase in the internal revenue enacted under such a
20 waiver shall be effective for not longer than two years.’’.

of America.

XVI.

Article eleven, section one, paragraph two, to be made

10 to read as follows:
11

-

"Each State shall be entitled to a number of electoral

12 votes equal to the whole number of Senators and Representa13

tives to which the State shall be entitled in Congress."

14

The first division of the twelfth amendment to the Con-

15

stitution, ending with the words, " directed to the President

16

of the Senate," to be struck out, and the following substituted:

17

"The citizens of each State who shall be qualified to vote

18

for Representatives in Congress shall cast their votes for can-

19

didates for President and Vice-President by ballot, and proper

20

returns of the votes so cast shall be made under seal, within

34

35

ively, and, if necessary, additional electoral votes for successive

36

largest fractions of a ratio shall be assigned to candidates voted

37

for until the whole number of the electoral votes of the State shall

be distributed; and the said officers shall thereupon make up

Title:: 114 H. J. Res. 80 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to prohibit gerrymandering in the establishment of Congressional districts.
TEXT_Content:
IA

114TH CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 80

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to prohibit
gerrymandering in the establishment of Congressional districts.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. GRAYSON

JANUARY 11, 2016
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to
the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to prohibit gerrymandering in the establishment
of Congressional districts.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3

Title:: 49 H. Res. 32 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
TEXT_Content:
49TH CONGBESS,
1ST SESSION.

H. RES. 32.

IN THE HOUSE 01 REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY

5, 1886.

Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed.

Mr. MOCOMAS introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
Whereas a legislative body sitting under a State constitution has
no right to sell, to give, or to bargain away forever the taxing
power of a State, or by contract to deprive the State forever
of the power of taxation, and thus destroy the Government
which it was appointed to serve ; and
Whereas in the principle of construction long approved by the
Supreme Court of the United States no hinderance can be
seen to rich corporations making contracts with legislatures
as they best may for perpetual exemption from all tne burdens of supporting the Government; and
Whereas the result of such a pri- ciple, under the growing tendency
to special and partial legislation, is to exempt the rich from
taxation and cast all the burden of the support of Government and the payment of its debts on those who are too poor
or too honest to purchase such immunity ; and
Whereas in many States of the Union favored corporations now
enjoy this immunity from taxation upon many millions of dollars' worth of property, rapidly multiplying in value, but perpetually free from taxes paid by the people : Therefore,

1

Besolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

[two-thirds of each House concurring therein). That the

4

following amendment to the Constitution of the United States

5

he, and hereby is, proposed; which, when ratified by the legis-

6

latures of three-fourths of the several States, shall he valid to

7

all intents and purposes as part of said Constitution: The first

8

clause of section ten, article one, shall be amended so as to

9

read as follows:

10

■ "No State shall enter into any treaty, alliance, or con-

11

federation; grant letters of marque and reprisal; coin money;

12

emit bills of credit; make anything but gold and silver coin a

13

tender in payment of debts; pass any bill of attainder, ex

14

post facto law, or law impairing the obligation of contracts;

15

or grant any title of nobility: Provided, however, That no

16

State shall be precluded by the grant of any charter or act of

17

incorporation from taxing the capital stock or property of

18

such corporation; nor shall any charter or act of incorporation

19

heretofore granted or that may hereafter be granted by any

20

State be construed to preclude the State from the power of

21

taxation ; but the States shall have and retain the full power

22

and right of taxation as if the prohibition to pass laws im-

23

pairing the obligation of contracts had never been incorporated

24

in this Constitution."

—

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MARCH 8, 1995
Mr. HILLEARY (for himself, Mr. NETHERCUTT, Mrs. MYRICK, Mr. MCINTOSH,
Mr. BRYANT of Tennessee, Mr. GRAHAM, Mr. ROYCE, Mr. LATOURETTE,
Mr. KINGSTON, Mr. WAMP, Mr. TATE, Mr. SALMON, Mr. WELLER, Mrs.
WALDHOLTZ, Mr. LATHAM, Mr. CHRISTENSEN, Mr. NORWOOD, Mr.
BROWNBACK, Mr. BASS, Mr. NEUMANN, Mrs. SMITH of Washington, Mr.
THORNBERRY, Mr. LARGENT, Mr. COBURN, Mr. TIAHRT, Mr. HUTCHINSON, Mr. STOCKMAN, Mr. PAXON, Mr. DICKEY, Mr. KLUG, and Mr. PETERSON of Minnesota) introduced the following joint resolution; which
was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States limiting the terms of office of Senators and Representatives.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

2
1 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
2 States within seven years after the date of its submission
3 for ratification:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person who has been elected to the

6 Senate two times shall be eligible for election or appoint7 ment to the Senate. No person who has been elected to
8 the House of Representatives six times shall be eligible
9 for election to the House of Representatives.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. Election as a Senator or Representative

11 before this Article is ratified shall not be taken into ac12 count for purposes of section 1, except that any State limi13 tation on service for Members of Congress from that
14 State, whether enacted before, on, or after the date of the
15 ratification of this Article shall be valid, if such limitation
16 does not exceed the limitation set forth in section 1.’’.

Title:: 105 S. J. Res. 28 (Introduced in the Senate)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States granting the President the authority to exercise an item veto of individual appropriations in an appropriations bill.
TEXT_Content:
IIA

105TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 28

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States granting
the President the authority to exercise an item veto of individual appropriations in an appropriations bill.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
Mr. ALLARD

APRIL 24, 1997
introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice
and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States granting the President the authority to exercise
an item veto of individual appropriations in an appropriations bill.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by
7 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with8 in 7 years after the date of its submission by the Congress:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The President shall have the power to

3 disapprove any appropriation of an appropriations bill at
4 the time the President approves the bill. The appropria5 tions in the bill not disapproved shall become law upon
6 approval by the President.
7

‘‘SECTION 2. If the President disapproves an appro-

8 priation pursuant to this article, in signing the bill con9 taining the appropriation, the President shall return a
10 copy of the disapproved appropriation, with a statement
11 of the reasons for the disapproval, to the House in which
12 the appropriations bill originated. The House in which the
13 appropriations bill originated may then reconsider the dis14 approved appropriation in a bill as provided for a bill re15 turned by the President under section 7 of article I. If
16 the bill is approved as provided under section 7 of article
17 I it shall become law.’’.

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. All citizens of the United States, who

3 are eighteen years of age or older, shall have the right
4 to vote in any public election held in the jurisdiction in
5 which the citizen resides. The right to vote shall not be
6 denied or abridged by the United States, any State, or
7 any other public or private person or entity, except that
8 the United States or any State may establish regulations
9 narrowly tailored to produce efficient and honest elections.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. Each State shall administer public elec-

11 tions in the State in accordance with election performance
12 standards established by the Congress. The Congress shall
13 reconsider such election performance standards at least
14 once every four years to determine if higher standards
15 should be established to reflect improvements in methods
16 and practices regarding the administration of elections.
17

‘‘SECTION 3. Each State shall provide any eligible

18 voter the opportunity to register and vote on the day of
19 any public election.
20

‘‘SECTION 4. Each State and the District constituting

21 the seat of Government of the United States shall estab22 lish and abide by rules for appointing its respective num23 ber of Electors. Such rules shall provide for the appoint24 ment of Electors on the day designated by the Congress

3 of the popular vote in the State or District.

‘‘SECTION 5. The Congress shall have power to en-

5 force this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

BAKER, Mr. BARR of Georgia, Mr. BARRETT of Nebraska, Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland, Mr. BASS, Mr. BILBRAY, Mr. BLILEY, Mr. BLUNT,

HEFLEY, Mr. HERGER, Mr. HILLEARY, Mr. HOEKSTRA, Mr. INGLIS of

Mr. KASICH, Mrs. KELLY, Mr. LAHOOD, Mr. LARGENT, Mr. LATHAM,

SCARBOROUGH, Mr. BOB SCHAFFER of Colorado, Mr. SENSENBRENNER,
Mr. SESSIONS, Mr. SHIMKUS, Mr. SMITH of Michigan, Mr. SMITH of New
Jersey, Mr. SMITH of Texas, Mrs. SMITH of Washington, Mr. SPENCE,

Mrs. FOWLER, Mr. CANNON, and Mr. SOLOMON) introduced the following
joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

2

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States with respect to tax limitations.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
8 States within seven years after the date of its submission
9 for ratification:
10
11

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. A bill to increase the internal revenue

12 shall require for final adoption in each House the concur13 rence of two-thirds of the whole number of that House,
14 unless that bill is determined at the time of adoption, in
15 a reasonable manner prescribed by law, not to increase
16 the internal revenue by more than a de minimis amount.
17

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress may waive the require-

18 ments of this article when a declaration of war is in effect.
19 The Congress may also waive this article when the United
20 States is engaged in military conflict which causes an im21 minent and serious threat to national security and is so
22 declared by a joint resolution, adopted by a majority of
•HJ 62 IH

3
1 the whole number of each House, which becomes law. Any
2 increase in the internal revenue enacted under such a
3 waiver shall be effective for not longer than two years.
4

‘‘SECTION 3. Congress shall enforce and implement

5 this article by appropriate legislation.’’.

Title:: 106 H. J. Res. 81 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to abolishing personal income, estate, and gift taxes and prohibiting the United States Government from engaging in business in competition with its citizens.
TEXT_Content:
IA

106TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 81

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative
to abolishing personal income, estate, and gift taxes and prohibiting
the United States Government from engaging in business in competition
with its citizens.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mr. PAUL

NOVEMBER 16, 1999
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relative to abolishing personal income, estate, and
gift taxes and prohibiting the United States Government
from engaging in business in competition with its citizens.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The Government of the United States

5 shall not engage in any business, professional, commercial,
6 financial, or industrial enterprise except as specified in the
7 Constitution.
8

‘‘SECTION 2. The constitution or laws of any State,

9 or the laws of the United States, shall not be subject to
10 the terms of any foreign or domestic agreement which
11 would abrogate this amendment.
12

‘‘SECTION 3. The activities of the United States Gov-

13 ernment which violate the intent and purposes of this
14 amendment shall, within a period of three years from the
15 date of the ratification of this amendment, be liquidated
16 and the properties and facilities affected shall be sold.
17

‘‘SECTION 4. Three years after the ratification of this

18 amendment the sixteenth article of amendments to the
19 Constitution of the United States shall stand repealed and
20 thereafter Congress shall not levy taxes on personal in21 comes, estates, and/or gifts.’’.

Æ

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘To secure the right of the People to acknowledge

3 God according to the dictates of conscience: Neither the
4 United States nor any State shall establish any official
5 religion, but the right of the People to pray and to recog6 nize their religious beliefs, heritage, or traditions on public
7 property, including schools, shall not be infringed. Neither
8 the United States nor any State shall require any person
9 to join in prayer or other religious activity, prescribe
10 school prayers, discriminate against religion, or deny equal
11 access to a benefit on account of religion.’’.

Title:: 109 H. J. Res. 14 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to abolishing personal income, estate, and gift taxes and prohibiting the United States Government from engaging in business in competition with its citizens.
TEXT_Content:
IA

109TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 14

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative
to abolishing personal income, estate, and gift taxes and prohibiting
the United States Government from engaging in business in competition
with its citizens.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 26, 2005
Mr. PAUL (for himself and Mr. FLAKE) introduced the following joint
resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relative to abolishing personal income, estate, and
gift taxes and prohibiting the United States Government
from engaging in business in competition with its citizens.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The Government of the United States

5 shall not engage in any business, professional, commercial,
6 financial, or industrial enterprise except as specified in the
7 Constitution.
8

‘‘SECTION 2. The constitution or laws of any State,

9 or the laws of the United States, shall not be subject to
10 the terms of any foreign or domestic agreement which
11 would abrogate this amendment.
12

‘‘SECTION 3. The activities of the United States Gov-

13 ernment which violate the intent and purposes of this
14 amendment shall, within a period of three years from the
15 date of the ratification of this amendment, be liquidated
16 and the properties and facilities affected shall be sold.
17

‘‘SECTION 4. Three years after the ratification of this

18 amendment the sixteenth article of amendments to the
19 Constitution of the United States shall stand repealed and
20 thereafter Congress shall not levy taxes on personal in21 comes, estates, and gifts.’’.

Æ

Title:: 107 H.R. 69 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Jo Ann H. Emerson (R - MO)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating to voluntary school prayer.
TEXT_Content:
I

107TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. R. 69

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating
to voluntary school prayer.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
Mrs. EMERSON

JANUARY 3, 2001
introduced the following bill; which was referred to the
Committee on the Judiciary

A BILL
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relating to voluntary school prayer.
1

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa-

2 tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 That the following article is hereby proposed as an amend4 ment to the Constitution of the United States, which shall
5 be valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Con6 stitution if ratified by the legislatures of at least three7 fourths of the several States within seven years from the
8 date of its proposal to the States by the Congress:

2
1
2

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to

3 prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or
4 other public institutions. No person shall be required by
5 the United States or by any State to participate in prayer.
6 Neither the United States nor any State shall prescribe
7 the content of any such prayer.’’

IA

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 5, 1993
Mr. EDWARDS of California (for himself, Mrs. SCHROEDER, Mr. ACKERMAN,
Mr. ANDREWS of Texas, Mr. ANDREWS of New Jersey, Mr. BACCHUS of
Florida, Mr. BEILENSON, Mr. BERMAN, Mr. BOUCHER, Mr. COLEMAN,
Mr. CONYERS, Mr. DEFAZIO, Mr. DELLUMS, Mr. DICKS, Mr. EVANS, Mr.

Mr. PANETTA, Mr. SABO, Mr. SHAYS, Ms. SLAUGHTER, Ms. SNOWE, Mr.
STARK, Mr. SWIFT, Mr. TOWNS, Mrs. UNSOELD, and Mr. FOGLIETTA)
introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relative to equal rights for men and women.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con-

2
1 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
2 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
3 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
4 States within seven years from the date of its submission
5 by the Congress:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Equality of rights under the law shall

8 not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any
9 State on account of sex.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. The Congress shall have the power to

11 enforce, by appropriate legislation, the provisions of this
12 article.
13

‘‘SECTION 3. This article shall take effect two years

14 after the date of ratification.’’.

28,1892.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to tlie Constitution of the United States
in relation to the election of President and Vice-President.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment to the Constitution of the United States

5

be proposed to the legislatures of the several States, which,

6

when ratified by three-fourths of said legislatures, shall become

7

a part of the Constitution, namely:

8
9
10

ARTICLE

XVI.

Article two, section one, paragraph two, to be made to
read as follows:

11

"Each State shall be entitled to a number of electoral

12

votes equal to the whole number of Senators and Representa-

13

tives to which the State shall be entitled in Congress."

14

The first division of the Twelfth Amendment to the Oon-

15

stitution, ending with the words ''directed to the President of

16

the Senate" to he stricken out and the following substituted:

17

"The citizens of each State who shall be qualified to

18

vote for Representatives in Congress shall cast their votes

19

for candidates for President and Yice-President by ballot, and

20

proper returns of the votes so cast shall be made under seal

21

within ten days to the secretary of state or other officer law-

22

fully performing the duties of such secretary in the govern-

23

ment of the State, by whom the said returns shall be publicly

24

opened in the presence of the chief executive magistrate of

25

the State and of the chief justice or judge of the highest court

26 thereof; and the said secretary, chief executive magistrate,
27

and judge shall assign to each candidate voted for by a sufficient

28

number of citizens a proportionate part of the electoral votes

29

to which the State shall be entitled, in manner following, that is

30

to say: They shall divide the whole number of votes returned

31

by the whole number of the State's electoral vote, and the

32

resulting quotient shall be the electoral ratio for the State, and

33

shall assign to candidates voted for one electoral vote for each

34 ratio of popular votes received by them, respectively, and, if
35

necessary, additional electoral votes for successive largest

36

fractions of a ratio shall be assigned to candidates voted for,

37

until the whole number of the electoral votes of the State shall

38

be distributed; and the said ofiicers shall thereupon make up

39

and certify at least three general returns, comprising the pop-

40

ular vote by counties, parishes, or other principal divisions of

41

the State, and their apportionment of electoral votes as afore-

42

said, and shall transmit two thereof, under seal, to the seat of

43

Government of the United States, one directed to the Presi-

44

dent of the Senate and one to the Speaker of the House of

45

Representatives, and a third unsealed return shall he forth-

46

with filed by the said secretary in his office, be recorded

47

therein and be at all times open to inspection."

48
49

Article two, section two, clause four, to be made to read
as follows:

50

"The Congress may determine the time of voting for

51

President and Vice-President, and the time of assigning elec-

52

toral votes to candidates voted for, which times shall be uni-

53

form throughout the United States.'

54'

Strike out the words "electors appointed" where they

55

occur in the Twelfth Amendment to the Constitution, and

56

substitute in their stead the words " electoral votes."

Title:: 102 S. J. Res. 237 (Introduced in the Senate)

102D CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. JL RES 237

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to set
the compensation of services for Members of Congress, and for other purposes.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
26 (legislative day, NOVEMBER 23), 1991
introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice
and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

NOVEMBER

Mr.

DASCHLE

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to set the compensation of services for Members
of Congress, and for other purposes.
1

Resolved, by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 That the following article is proposed as an amendment
4 to the Constitution of the United States, to be valid only
5 if ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several
6 States within seven j^ears after the date of its submission
7 by the Congress:
8
9

"ARTICLE —

"The Congress shall make no law affecting the com-

10 pensation for services for Members of Congress. On Janu-

2

2 compensation of Members of Congress shall be adjusted
3 to correspond to any increase or decrease in the median
4 income of all citizens of the United States.".

Title:: 104 H. J. Res. 27 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States barring Federal unfunded mandates to the States.

IA

104TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 27

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States barring
Federal unfunded mandates to the States.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
JANUARY 4, 1995
Mr. FRANKS of New Jersey (for himself, Mr. CONDIT, Mr. BLUTE, Mr. EMERSON, Mr. SMITH of Texas, Mr. SAXTON, Mr. LOBIONDO, Mr.
FRELINGHUYSEN, and Ms. DANNER) introduced the following joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States barring Federal unfunded mandates to the States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when
7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

2
1 States within seven years after the date of its submission
2 for ratification:
3
4

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. Except as provided in section 2, no obli-

5 gation imposed by or pursuant to an Act of Congress upon
6 a State shall be enforceable against that State unless the
7 Federal Government provides to the State the money
8 needed to pay the State’s cost of complying with the obli9 gation, and no condition imposed by or pursuant to an
10 Act of Congress on the receipt of Federal assistance by
11 a State shall be enforceable against that State unless the
12 condition is directly and substantially related to the spe13 cific subject matter of the assistance. For the purposes
14 of this article, a State includes any subdivision or instru15 mentality of any of the several States.
16

‘‘SECTION 2. Congress may, by separate Act of Con-

17 gress addressed solely to a single Act of Congress impos18 ing an obligation or making a condition for assistance that
19 would otherwise not take effect by reason of section 1,
20 make an exception to section 1 of this article with respect
21 to that obligation or condition. However, any Act of Con22 gress making such an exception shall not take effect unless
23 agreed to by two-thirds of the members of each House.’’.
24

‘‘SECTION 3. A judicial order enforcing this article

25 may direct that an obligation or condition is not enforce•HJ 27 IH

3
1 able against a State, but shall not direct that the Federal
2 Government provide to the State money needed to pay the
3 State’s cost of complying with the obligation.
4

‘‘SECTION 4. Section 1 of this article applies only

5 with respect to an obligation or condition that first takes
6 effect after the date of the ratification of this article.’’.

Title:: 50 H. Res. 7 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States in relation to the election of President and Vice-President, providing for their election by a majority of the votes of the people and the abolition of the electoral college, and regulating the method of counting the votes by the two Houses of Congress.
TEXT_Content:
50TH UOWUKESS,
1ST SESSION.

H. RES, 7.

IN THE HOUSE OE REPRESENTATIVES,
JANUARY

4,1888.

Eead twice, referred to the Select Committee on the Election of President, VicePresident, and Eepresentatives in Congress, and ordered to be printed.

Mr. TOWNSHEND introduced the following joint resolution:

JOINT [RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
in relation to the election of President and Vice-President,
providing for their election by a majority of the votes of the
people and the abolition of the Electoral College, and regulating the method of counting the votes by the two Houses of
Congress.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled

3

[two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4

following amendment to the Constitution of the United States

5

be proposed to the legislatures of the several States; which,

6

when ratified by three-fourths of said legislatures, shall be-

7

come and be a part of the Constitution, namely:

8
9
10
11

AETICLE

XVI.

The second and third divisions of article second shall be
struck out.
All that part of the twelfth amendment of the Constitu-

12

tion from the beginning down to and including the words "if

13

such number be a majority of the whole number of electors

14

appointed" to be struck out, and the following substituted:

15

" Hereafter the President and Vice-President of the United

16

States shall be chosen by the people of the respective States

17

in the following manner:

18

" The citizens of each State who shall be qualified to vote

19

for members of Congress shall, on the first Tuesday after the

20

first Monday in November, in the year eighteen hundred and

21

eighty-four, and on the same day in every four years thereafter,

22

cast their votes by ballot for candidates for President and

23

Vice-President, one of whom at least shall not be an

24

inhabitant of the State with himself; and proper returns of

25

the votes so cast shall be made under seal, within ten days,

2Q

to the chief justice or to the presiding judge of the highest

27 judicial tribunal in the State.
28

"The right of fixing the places in the State where the

29

election shall be held, and the manner of holding the same and

30

of canvassing the votes and certifying the returns to the said

31

chief justice or presiding judge, is reserved exclusively to the

32

legislatures of the States.

33

" The highest judicial tribunal of each State shall meet

34

and be in session on the second Tuesday next following said

35

election, and the presiding judge of said tribunal shall pub-

36

licly open said returns in the presence of the members of the

3i

said tribunal, and the votes shall then be counted by the said

38

tribunal.

39

nal to cause three certificates of the numbers of votes so cast

40

in said State for President and Vice-President to be made

41

and certified by a majority of the members of said tribunal

42

and attested by the seal of said tribunal.

43
44
45

It shall be the duty of the members of said tribu-

"The certificates of the members of said tribunal shall
be disposed of by them in the following manner:
"First. They shall, by writing, under the hands of a ma-

46 jority of them, appoint a person to take charge of and deliver
47

to the President of the Senate, at the seat of Government, be-

48

fore the first Monday in December next after their meeting,

49

one of the certificates.

50

"Second. They shall forthwith forward, by the post-

51

office, to the President of the Senate, at the seat of Govern-

52

ment, one other of the certificates.

53

" Third. They shall forthwith cause the other of the cer-

54

tificates to be delivered to the judge of that district in which

55

the tribunal shall assemble.

56

"Whenever a certificate of votes from any State shah not

57

be received by the President of the Senate on or before the

58

day indicated in the preceding section, he shall forthwith

59

notify the said presiding judge, who shall send a special mes-

60

senger to the district judge in whose custody one certificate

61

of the-votes from that State has been lodged, and such judge

62

shall forthwith transmit that certificate to the seat of Govern-

63

ment.

64
65

"Congress shall be in session on the second Monday in
December succeeding every election of President.

66

"The Senate and House of Representatives shall meet

67

in the Hall of the House of Representatives at one o'clock

68

post meridiem on that day ; the President of the Senate shall

69

be their presiding officer.

70

" Two tellers shall be previously appointed on the part

71

of the Senate and two on the part of the House of Represent-

72

atives.

73

" The President of the Senate shall then open all the cer-

74

tificates, and papers purporting to be certificates, of the elect-

75

oral votes; the votes shall then be counted by the two Houses

76

of Congress in the alphabetical order of the States.

77

" The person having the greatest number of votes cast in

78

all the States for President shall be President, if such num-

79

ber be equal to a majority of the whole vote given; but

80

if no person have such a majority, then a second election

81

shall be held on the second Tuesday after the first Monday in

82

the month of January then next ensuing, between the per-

83

sons having the two highest numbers for the office of Presi-

84

dent, which second election shall be conducted, the result

85

certified, and the votes counted in the same manner as in

86

the first; and the person having the greatest number of

87

votes for President shall be President.

But if two or more

88

persons shall have received the greatest and equal number

89

of votes at the second, election, the House of Representatives

90

shall choose one of them for President, as is now prescribed

91

by the Constitution.

92

"The person having the greatest number of votes for

93

Vice-President at the first election shall be the Vice-Presi-

94

dent, if such number be equal to a majority of the whole

95

number of votes given; and if no person have such majority,

96

then a second election shall take place between the persons

97

having the two highest numbers on the same day that the

98

second election is held for President; and the person having

99

the highest number of votes for Vice-President shall be the

100

Vice-President.

But if two or more persons shall have re-

101

ceived the greatest number of votes in the second election,

102

then the Senate shall choose one of them for Vice-President,

103

as is now provided in the Constitution.

104

election shall be necessary in the case of Vice:President, and

105

not necessary in the case of President, then the Senate shall

106

choose a Vice-President from the persons having the two

107

highest numbers in the first election, as is prescribed in the

108

Constitution."

But when a second

109

Strike out from the twelfth amendment the words

110

"from the persons having the highest numbers, not exceeding

111

three, on the list of those voted for as President."

6
112

Strike out the words "electors appointed" where they

113

occur in the twelfth amendment, and insert the words " votes

114

cast at the election."

Title:: 50 S. Res. 86 (Ordered to be Printed Senate)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States respecting establishments of religion and free public schools.
TEXT_Content:
50TH UOINtfKESS.
2D SESSION.

S. R, 86.

IN THE SENATE OE THE UNITED STATES.
MAY

Mr.

BLAIR

25,1888.

introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and
ordered to lie on the table.
MARCH

2, 1889.

Ordered to be reprinted.

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
respecting establishments of religion and free public schools.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3

(two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the

4 following amendment to the Constitution of the United
5

States be, and hereby is, proposed to the States, to become

6

valid when ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the

7

States as provided in the Constitution:

8
9

AETIOLE
SECTION

1. No State shall ever make or maintain any

10 law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the
11
12
13

free exercise thereof.
SEC.

2. Each State in this Union shall establish and

maintain a system of free public schools adequate for the ed-

14

ucation of all the children living therein, between the ages of six

15

and sixteen years, inclusive, in the common branches of knowl-

16

edge, and in virtue, morality, and the principles of the Christ-

17

ian religion.

18

law or any money or other property or credit belonging to

19

any municipal organization, or to any State, or to the United

20

States, shall ever be appropriated, applied, or given to the use

21

or purposes of any school, institution, corporation, or person,

22

whereby instruction or training shall be given in the doctrines,

23

tenets, belief, ceremonials, or observances peculiar to any sect,

24

denomination, organization, or society, being, or claiming to

25

be, religious in its character, nor shall such peculiar doctrines,

26

tenets, belief, ceremonials, or observances, be taught or incul-

27

cated, in the free public schools.

28

SEC.

But no money raised by taxation imposed by

3. To the end that each State, the United States,

29

and all the people thereof, may have and preserve govern-

30

ments republican in form and in substance, the United States

31

shall guaranty to every State, and to the people of every

32

State and of the United States, the support and maintenance

33

of such a system of free public schools as is herein provided.

34
35

SEC.

4. That Congress shall enforce this article by legis-

lation when necessary.

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative
to limiting the number of terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

Mr. VITTER (for himself, Mr. PAUL, Ms. AYOTTE, Mr. COBURN, Mr. LEE, Mr.
RUBIO, Mr. CRUZ, Mr. TOOMEY, and Mr. JOHNSON of Wisconsin) introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and referred
to the Committee on the Judiciary

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States relative to limiting the number of terms that
a Member of Congress may serve.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all

18 the ratification of this article shall be taken into account
19 in determining eligibility for election or appointment under
20 this article.’’.
