Title:: 103 H. J. Res. 324 (Introduced in the House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of years an individual may serve in certain positions in the Government of the United States, and for other purposes.
TEXT_Content:
IA

103D CONGRESS
2D SESSION

H. J. RES. 324

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit
the number of years an individual may serve in certain positions in
the Government of the United States, and for other purposes.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FEBRUARY 10, 1994
Mr. SARPALIUS (for himself and Mr. BREWSTER) introduced the following
joint resolution; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to limit the number of years an individual may
serve in certain positions in the Government of the
United States, and for other purposes.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two3 thirds of each House concurring therein), That the follow4 ing article is proposed as an amendment to the Constitu5 tion of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents
6 and purposes as part of the Constitution when ratified by

2
1 the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States with2 in seven years after the date of its submission for ratifica3 tion:
4
5

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. No person may serve in the United

6 States Government in the following positions, either indi7 vidually or cumulatively, for more than 12 years:
8

‘‘(1) President of the United States.

9

‘‘(2) Vice-President of the United States.

10

‘‘(3) Member of the Cabinet of the President.

11

‘‘(4) Senator or Representative in, or Resident

12

Commissioner or Delegate to, the Congress.

13

‘‘(5) Positions located within the District of Co-

14

lumbia or a contiguous area for which appointment

15

by the President is required, by and with the advice

16

and consent of the Senate.

17
18

‘‘(6) Justice of the Supreme Court.
‘‘SECTION 2. This article shall apply to the Justices

19 serving on the Supreme Court as of the date of ratification
20 of this article as follows: one year after the date of the
21 first Presidential election after ratification, the term of the
22 Justice who has the most seniority on the Supreme Court,
23 and who has exceeded the limitation on service set forth
24 in section 1, shall end; and one year after the date of each
25 Presidential election thereafter, the term of the Justice
•HJ 324 IH

3
1 who then has the most seniority on the Supreme Court,
2 and who has exceeded the limitation on service set forth
3 in section 1, shall end.
4

‘‘SECTION 3. For purposes of this article and except

5 as provided in section 2, service in a position referred to
6 in section 1 before ratification of this article shall be in7 cluded in determining the number of years served. A per8 son serving in an elected position on the date of ratifica9 tion of this article may serve out the remainder of the term
10 of that position, regardless of whether that person has ex11 ceeded the limitation on service set forth in section 1.’’.

Title:: 51 H. Res. 142 (Referred to Committee House)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States providing for the election of Senators by the qualified voters of the several States.
TEXT_Content:
51ST CONGRESS,
1ST SESSION.

H. RES. 142.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
APRIL

4,1890.

Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed

Mr. HENDERSON, of North Carolina, introduced the following joint
resolution:

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
providing for the election of Senators by the qualified voters
of the several States.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2

of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

3

That the following amendment to the Constitution of the

4

United States be proposed to the legislatures of the several

5

States, which, when ratified by three-fourths of said legisla-

6

tures, shall become and be a part of the Constitution, namely:

7

First. Amend the first clause of section three of article one

8

of the Constitution so that said clause shall read as follows:

9

" The Senate of the United States shall be composed of two

10

Senators from each State, chosen by the people thereof for six

11

years, and each Senator shall have one vote, and the electors

12

in each State shall have the qualifications requisite *for elec-

13

tors of the most numerous branch of the State legislature."

14

Second. Amend the second clause of section three of

15

article one of the Constitution by striking out all after the

16

word "otherwise" in said clause, and substituting the follow-

17

ing: "The executive authority of the Sta,te shall issue writs

18

of election to fill such vacancies."

Title:: 108 S. J. Res. 1 (Introduced in the Senate)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect the rights of crime victims.
TEXT_Content:
IIA

108TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

S. J. RES. 1

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to protect
the rights of crime victims.

IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
JANUARY 7, 2003
Mr. KYL (for himself and Mrs. FEINSTEIN) introduced the following joint resolution; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States to protect the rights of crime victims.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the
4 following article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States:
6
7

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. The rights of victims of violent crime,

8 being capable of protection without denying the constitu9 tional rights of those accused of victimizing them, are
10 hereby established and shall not be denied by any State

2
1 or the United States and may be restricted only as pro2 vided in this article.
3

‘‘SECTION 2. A victim of violent crime shall have the

4 right to reasonable and timely notice of any public pro5 ceeding involving the crime and of any release or escape
6 of the accused; the rights not to be excluded from such
7 public proceeding and reasonably to be heard at public re8 lease, plea, sentencing, reprieve, and pardon proceedings;
9 and the right to adjudicative decisions that duly consider
10 the victim’s safety, interest in avoiding unreasonable
11 delay, and just and timely claims to restitution from the
12 offender. These rights shall not be restricted except when
13 and to the degree dictated by a substantial interest in pub14 lic safety or the administration of criminal justice, or by
15 compelling necessity.
16

‘‘SECTION 3. Nothing in this article shall be con-

17 strued to provide grounds for a new trial or to authorize
18 any claim for damages. Only the victim or the victim’s
19 lawful representative may assert the rights established by
20 this article, and no person accused of the crime may obtain
21 any form of relief hereunder.
22

‘‘SECTION 4. Congress shall have power to enforce

23 by appropriate legislation the provisions of this article.
24 Nothing in this article shall affect the President’s author25 ity to grant reprieves or pardons.
•SJ 1 IS

3
1

‘‘SECTION 5. This article shall be inoperative unless

2 it has been ratified as an amendment to the Constitution
3 by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several States
4 within 7 years from the date of its submission to the
5 States by the Congress. This article shall take effect on
6 the 180th day after the date of its ratification.’’.

Æ

•SJ 1 IS

Title:: 110 H. J. Res. 28 (Introduced in the House)
Bill Sponsor:: Representative Jesse Louis Jackson Jr. (D - IL)
Summary: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States regarding the right to vote.
TEXT_Content:
IA

110TH CONGRESS
1ST SESSION

H. J. RES. 28

Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States regarding
the right to vote.

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
FEBRUARY 13, 2007
Mr. JACKSON of Illinois (for himself, Mr. BISHOP of Georgia, Ms. CORRINE
BROWN of Florida, Mrs. CHRISTENSEN, Mr. CLEAVER, Mr. CUMMINGS,
Mr. FATTAH, Mr. GRIJALVA, Ms. KILPATRICK, Mr. JOHNSON of Georgia,
Mr. MEEK of Florida, Ms. NORTON, Mr. RUSH, Mr. STARK, Ms. WOOLSEY, and Mr. WYNN) introduced the following joint resolution; which was
referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

JOINT RESOLUTION
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United
States regarding the right to vote.
1

Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives

2 of the United States of America in Congress assembled
3 (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the fol4 lowing article is proposed as an amendment to the Con5 stitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all
6 intents and purposes as part of the Constitution when

7 ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the several

‘‘ARTICLE —
‘‘SECTION 1. All citizens of the United States who

3 are eighteen years of age or older shall have the right to
4 vote in any public election held in the jurisdiction in which
5 the citizen resides. The right to vote shall not be denied
6 or abridged by the United States, any State, or any other
7 public or private person or entity, except that the United
8 States or any State may establish regulations narrowly
9 tailored to produce efficient and honest elections.
10

‘‘SECTION 2. Each State shall administer public elec-

11 tions in the State in accordance with election performance
12 standards established by the Congress. The Congress shall
13 reconsider such election performance standards at least
14 once every four years to determine if higher standards
15 should be established to reflect improvements in methods
16 and practices regarding the administration of elections.
17

‘‘SECTION 3. Each State shall provide any eligible

18 voter the opportunity to register and vote on the day of
19 any public election.
20

‘‘SECTION 4. The Congress shall have power to en-

21 force and implement this article by appropriate legisla22 tion.’’.
